♥♥♥♥ this game. Literally ♥♥♥♥ this game.

Why? Because it is actually really REALLY FUN. And THAT is exactly the Problem!

How so you ask? Simple! Because it is yet another free-to-play, pay-to-win game. It is a good game disguising a hideous marketing strategy. It is absolutely repulsive.

Because you're gonna start playing this game and go Oh man! This game is really fun! I want to keep playing it!" but then slowly the realization starts to seep in... YOU CAN'T. Why not? Well

reviewText:
This game was/is not much different then many other match 3 games except that you use characters to beat up other characters.

It was quite fun and a way to waste a few hours just battling it out.  But then they did a few changes which made it so that if you wanted to progress you had to do whats called grinding (for those that don't know, thats when you have to spend 5 or 6 hours playing just to keep up with others playing).  This made things less fun.

Now for the biggest change, if you have any characters that can heal the team during combat its called false healing.  Basically what happens is that while in a round, they will heal your characters, but soon as its done, any and all damage that was done to your character during a round gets applied to your characters, which means they will more then likely be instantly down and you have to wait somewhere between 3 and 14 hours for them to heal.

So now instead of being able to play for a couple of hours, you're lucky if you get in a couple of rounds that can last about 5 to 10 minutes at most and then you need to wait till the next day (least for those of us with families, work and who require sleep) to play for another 10 minutes and then wait.

They wanted to stop people from using their healing characters in story mode to heal their wounded characters and instead buy heath packs, which cost Hero Points which while they do come in game, they are very rare in game and they expect more people to buy Hero Points so they can buy health pack.  This has basically turned the game into pay 2 win game, well it was before but now its much worse.

The majority of people who play F2P games will never actually put money into free 2 play games.  Once it gets to the point where they are spending more then a few hours playing and not being able to keep up with their friends, they loose interest and leave, and start bad mouthing the game, which causes people not to go play that game, which means the game looses lots of money.


So for now I can not recommend this game.  Maybe if the devs wise up and actually listen to the community and things go back to how they were a couple of months ago, may I will start playing again and maybe even recommend this game, but lots of things have to change.

reviewText:
=== August 2014 Edit ===

Nope, still sucks.

=== March 2014 Edit ===

Well, it's not fun anymore. I play just for the sake of it, but it's starting to feel extremely grindy and pay2win-ish.

They keep adding more paid or extremely expensive features (started with Shields, now with Alliances spots - 600 Hero Points for a new spot!!), don't care about balance, our ISO-8 pool is suffering a big hit (they reduced several rewards, now it's really hard to get a good ISO flow).

I think the final nail in the coffin was that very lame Modern Thor. It's just too much. I don't know if they're lacking resources or whatever, but making a character completely obsolete, and giving more health to the most annoying character in tournaments... lame.
Also, the Funbalance" patch went to the crapper with that. Now they just have to add a Gold Wolverine and that will be it.

I think nowadays

reviewText:
When this first came out, I really wanted to like it.  Heck, when it first came out, I DID like it.  I'm going to go straight to my pros and cons.

PROS:
1) Classic Puzzle Quest gameplay - If you have enjoyed any of the other PQ games, the gameplay is back.  You get 3 characters on your team, who provide 1-3 abilities each.  It's still fun and addicting.  This is not my problem with the game at all.
2) Big cast - There are 33 characters and counting in this game.  Each brings something new to the table.  Sure, several of the characters are different versions of the another character (there are 3 different Wolverines), but they usually play differently enough that you won't mind.

CONS:
1) Poorly timed updates - In a game like this, nerfs are a fact of life.  But nerfing a character in the middle of an event that focuses on that character is a jerk move.  Especially now that they are introducing...
2) Tournaments with entrance fees - This might not be so bad if it had been there from the start, but as a new feature, it feels like the wrong direction for the game.  To make matters worse, you can't find out the available characters for use in the  tournament until AFTER paying the costs.
3) Rising costs - There are several neat features that were introduced as crutches to help players with weaker rosters, like Shields to protect against attacks in PVP and Boosts (extra starting energy or damage) to give yourself an extra edge.  These started off being available at a decent price, but then skyrocketed without warning after everyone came to depend on them.
4) Speed-run - I don't know about you, but I like to play games at my own pace, and you can in this game... for the Prologue.  After that, each chapter is available for a limited time and disappears at the end of that time.  I completely missed Chapter 1 because of this and if you are starting now, it might be too late for you to see Chapter 2 as well.  This is made worse by the fact that some of the fights in these chapters have opponents with levels over 200 (your characters are capped at 141 until you manage to level the very rarest characters) and the fact that some levels are UNPLAYABLE unless you have a specific character in your roster!  Missing part of the story because you couldn't get a 4* Invisible Woman (the rarest character) is unacceptable.
5) Slow leveling - When I started playing, this was my biggest complaint, but I adapted to it.  I would have still recommended this if it were the only problem.  However, it is still a problem you should be aware of.  Characters require THREE forms of leveling.  First, you need covers acquire or level up your skills.  Second, there is a very rare form of currency called Hero Points that can replace the need for covers, but you will likely need it for other purposes, because it is very rare unless you pay to buy more of it with real currency.  Third, you need ISO, which is the experience of the game.  At first, you'll think you are getting a ton of it, because low level characters can get a level after a fight or two.  Once your characters start to get mid-level, you will need to win ~20 fights to level a single character by one level.  With 30+ characters that have a max level anywhere from 50 to 230, you will need a LOT of ISO and even buying it with cash won't help because it is crazy expensive.

SUMMARY
I love the gameplay and being able to play with Marvel superheroes.  I was willing to cope with the slow leveling until the developers started making a ton of poor decisions that favored those who are insanely high-leveled or spending cash.  I want to love this game, and if it had been released as a Single-Player game like all of the others, I probably would.  But the way it is, I just can't.

reviewText:
After 280 hours played, I'm finally done with the game. But at the very least I should be able to give people a very thorough review of the game.

At 280 hours played, the game can't be that bad, right? So why stop now?

The core of the game is still really cool. You build up a roster of Marvel heroes and villians and level them up to build a stronger and stronger team. And the devs support the game relatively well with new events and new heroes so there is always something to do.

Still, they just pushed it too far. This game isn't really a game, it's a second job. I see no way to play this game casually, either you are all in or you are out. Every two weeks there is a new hero, accompanied by a 10 day long PvE event that's a pure battle of attrition to defend a placement in the leaderboards high enough to get the new hero. If you don't? Without the new hero you'll have already lost in the next tournament. The new always gives a insurmountable advantage for the next. There is no way to escape this sweatshop.

And the PvE events are less fun with each iteration. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ rubber banding and level scaling makes PvE tournaments an exercise in frustration and disappointment. Have a maxed out Lv141 roster? Enjoy being beaten in placement by Level 50 teams, because their enemies get scaled to level 20 and take 1 minute each while you slog it out against Lv300 enemies with 10k HP each.

And then the PvP tournaments... They used to be great. But then they changed the match making algorithm so that now every fight is a tired slog. And since there is now always an Alliance season running, you HAVE to do well in every single PvP tournament non stop or you are letting down your alliance.

Alliances are another thing... they are great socially. But the pressure they put you under is enourmous. And again, it's all in or all out. Without being in a good alliance, you'll miss 30% of each tournament's reward! You might as well not bother if you aren't in an alliance.

And the time commitment required to stay in the game is 2 hours EVERY SINGLE DAY. And even that is sometimes not enough, with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ending times in the middle of the night for EU players which means all your effort is wasted thanks to rubber banding of US players near the end of the tournament while you are sleeping.

Just do yourself a favor and don't get involved in this game. It's a bottomless black hole that you can't escape from.

Why I quit now and not weeks ago? Season 1 just ended and I could finally leave without ♥♥♥♥ing over my alliance. They are great people and they didn't deserve being abandoned halfway through the season.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, but the path chosen by the developers makes this one of the most frustrating experiences with a game I have ever had. The hours I have listed on this game are not technically accurate as I had it running in the background for days/weeks at a time. However I have easily put in 100's of hours into trying to like this game, hoping that the devs would fix the issues and it would improve. Ultimately I finally realized that there was near zero chance that would happen because the devs want the game to be this way.

First the lets talk about the good - If you enjoy PuzzleQuest you will like the mechanics, the incorporation of the Marvel license is topnotch both with writing and character design. If you can be content with just playing the story missions and only a small subset of the available champions then go ahead.

However if you are like me and want to play with the new champions when they are released and play the special events then you will pay. And if you pay realize that it is only a matter of time before that which you paid for is nerfed or sidelined or otherwise invalidated by whatever the newest cash grab from D3 is.

Here is how it works, lets say you have a set of beginning characters (called 2 star for their rarity) and are having fun. You see that a new character is being released (omg Nick Furry?! I want to play that one too!). In order to get covers for that character you have to buy them with real money, oh except you can't really buy them straight you have to buy a pack" and hope you get the covers you want (along with a bunch of stuff you don't want). If you aren't willing to go that route then you will have to jump through some very specific hoops
date: namely you will be "competing" with other players for a chance to win the cover. You do this by direct competition (through a very very broken PvP style contest that I am not even going to get into its so bad) or by grinding away at special missions
recommended: missions that are designed to be overpowering and that will wound or kill your characters (requiring you to "rest" or buy medpacks with money). I don't know if I can stress how grindy these missions will be if you actually want a shot at the new cover
hoursPlayed: we are talking hours of playtime
voteText: but what is even worse is D3 picks the times you need to play. This is ultimately why I had to stop
helpfulPercent: in order to be successful with the rubber-banding and the like you had to be playing near the finish of each sub-event and each main event. That means you can't even just grind it out on your own time you needed to be hardcore during specific hours (forgot real life commitments). What I finally realized was there is no end game. That process described above is it. It doesn't get easier just harder
votesHelpful: and not from a skill level just from a time commitment and frustration level. D3's entire model is to reward low level players greater then high level players to make them think rewards are quick and easy. Once you are hooked however you will constantly lose you chance at the new covers to the next wave of new players getting their hooks set. No only do I not recommend this to anyone I would be very cautious about ever playing anything from D3.\n"

reviewText: There is NO need to buy ANY DLC of this F2P one. Just ignore the micro-transactions. Honestly, you can get unlimited Iso-8/Hero Points/whatever in-game currencies using Cheat Engine to make yourself happy. Collecting the awesome characters is fun, but the user experience is bad. High CPU usage, laggy during loading, and not-user-friendly UI. You can only draw one card at a time and cannot sell them all at once. You have to move and click your mouse frequently to get things done. And it's difficult to get a Legendary character (Invisible Woman), the possibility is about 1% I think. It's difficult to earn Hero Points as well. Versus system doesn't make any sense, you're still playing with AI. And the most important thing is, if you try to level up some of your favorite characters, it will cost you more than 100k of Iso-8 to the cap. I tried so hard to enjoy this Marvel-flavored Puzzle Quest, but I failed. This game shouldn't be called Puzzle Quest IMO.

reviewText:
TL;DR - Avoid at all costs! I'm in too deep but it may not be too late for you.

I've been playing the version on iOS since October last year and a lot has changed. The game deals in ISO and Hero Points. ISO is common but you'll need lots and Hero Points are uncommon but both are required. How much you'll enjoy this game will depend on how much money and time you'll be OK with sinking into this hole.
You collect covers of characters. Each cover is arranged in a 1-4 star configuration. 1* = common, 4* = super rare. How you can get covers is by either winning tournaments or by earning standard or heroic tokens and lucking in to a cover you require. A standard token would typically give you 1* cover with a sprinking of 2* cover and the day you get a 3* cover go get a lotto ticket. Heroic tokens are hard to come across but you can get anywhere up to 19 Heroic Tokens (personal experience) before you get a 3* cover. Why covers of characters and not the characters themselves? Because you can have more than one cover of the same character! Yes! Lazy! For instance, there are 3 covers of Storm - a 1*, 2* and 3* cover. Wolverine has 3 covers - a 2*, 3* and 4*. Thor has 3 covers - 2*, 3* and 4*, etc.
On top of that, most covers have 3 coloured moves and a maximum of 12 covers per chracter. Eg. Iron Man Model 40 (3*) - Unibeam (red), Ballistic Salvo (blue) and Recharge (yellow) (minus Bullseye (2*), Dr Doom (3*), Ragnarok (3*), Loki (3*) who all have 2 moves and a maximum of 10 covers). Meaning in order to max out your character, you need 12 covers and A LOT of ISO to level it up to full level. 1* covers level up to level 40, 2* = level 94, 3* = level 166 and 4* = level 270. Also, each cover takes up 1 roster slot. You can buy more with hero points!
You can buy cover packs with hero points/real money. They come in 1, 10, 42 packs. The amount of REAL money for hero points in this game is highway robbery. There is 0 value. If you were to spend money on this game, it would be in hero points but the little hero points you get for your hard earnt money is not even close to worth it. When you purchase a pack (because the only other time you can earn a 10 pack is through the season rewards), it USED TO guarantee at least one 3* cover. But they took that away because screw consumers. They don't want people having all the good covers by simply getting a cheap" (it's not cheap) 10 pack with at least one guaranteed 3* cover in it. No no

reviewText: Bait and switch microtransaction galore... you would expect a match-three game to be casual, but actually if you want to get anywhere in this game you must play at least an hour and a half every eight hours every day, every night - its a grindy borefest. The company doesnt care about playerbase, they just want to squeeze money from people before they eventually realize the game sucks and quit.

reviewText:
Once upon a time, this was a fun game to play.
Hell, it's been some time since I've actually devoted this much time on a game.
But, now... this 'game' has become - to paraphrase a forum post from developer's website -,
a hybrid of a sick joke and a straigh fraud.

Before we start, let me introducte two 'resource' types in this game.
ISOs and HPs.
ISOs are akin to experience points, which you get by playing. Sure, you can buy.  But technically you can just invest time into the game to overcome that.
HPs are hard to come by on its own and to get any respectable quantity, you have to buy.

Sounds bad, huh? But no, the beauty of this game was that you could potentially outwit opponents with far stronger characters by timely use of boosts and strategic thinking in organising your team.


And do you know what the geniuses at d3p came up with for 'improving the game experience'?
1) change the currency of key boost in-game from ISO to HP -> thereby turning game into dime-a-dozen pay2win variety.
2) increase cost of other boosts by 100%
3) introduce a pvp tournament only open to those who can pay with HP... -> again pay2win only
4) ...then nerfing the key characters in mid-competition -> just breathetaking stupidity...

and the funny thing?
(1),(2) & (3) were given no notice of update what-so-ever.
So, the end result is a bunch of guys and girls being shafted by what is (at best) a questionable practise from the developers.

If anyone really wants to play Marvel related games, do look for something else.
Don't waste time like an idiot as I did on this monumental piece of greedy ♥♥♥♥-up.

reviewText: This game has the potential to be a great match-3 type game.  I thouroughly enjoyed the original Puzzle Quest game so I thought I'd give this a try.  I was really enjoying it until I realized how much money will need to be dumped into the game to unlock things that are needed.  The microtransactions in this game are ridiculous!  I have no problem throwing a few bucks here and there at a dev that has a quality product, but the costs are so bad that it's not worth my time.  Reduce the cost of the microtransactions and I MIGHT play it again.

reviewText:
I enjoy the gameplay.  It could be a really awesome game......  I said COULD be.  But the DLC and the mecanics of the game that make it nearly a must buy totally ruin it.

I was in the top 50 in the opening competition and I have the Black Widow character to prove it.  I have not spent any money in DLC yet but I see the mechanics of the game that make it nearly impossible to play long term without doing so.  This is coming from someone who has spent a good deal of time playing this game.  I've also played previous games in the series like original Puzzle Quest and Puzzle Quest: Galactrix.

In order to increase your roster size you have to pay coins, which are nearly impossible to get without paying real money.  If you don't add a character to your roster within 7 days the character goes bye bye.  That means you have to either delete a character that you've probably built up or spend real money.

If you want to continue to play you have to keep your characters healed.  However, there's no way to get healing other than wait forever, which stops you from playing, or buy them, which requires real money again.  If you want to build your characters up any faster than a snails pace you have to spend real money again.  Around every corner of this game is a need to spend real money.

Folks, there is a good way to do DLC and there is a bad way to do DLC.  This game is a shining example of the bad way to do DLC.  I would have much rather paid $20.00 for a great game then had options to buy non-gameplay breaking DLC such as special skins for the hero's, backgrounds, or gem skins.  As the game stands it deserves every single comment it receives about greedy developers.
voteText: 39 of 57 people (68%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have played this game over 350 hours, and I have only put $1 into this game, which was when I first started playing. Personaly, I do not recommend that anyone put money into this game because a lot of people have already done that, so the outcome would be rather disapointing, but that is left to your discretion.

This game has very interesting machanics for a puzzle game and the fact that it is Marvel is very cool. I also enjoy the animations for the character abilities. Additionally, the story content is usually humorous and fun to follow.

The game has changed in a few ways over the last year.

First, when I started playing this game it was almost imposible to win in PvP or random events because people that put lots of money into the game had better characters at much higher levels. However, I continued to play and found ways to deal with it. But there is better news for new players. The game has been switched so that players are paired with other players around thier average level. So basically add all your character levels and divide by the number of characters. This machanic also tries to push people away from the idea of getting one high level character because it would offset your team average and put you at a disadvantage in a higher tier.

Originally, there were certain lower level characters with overpowered abilities, which have since been nerfed or changed to even out lower tiers because earning certain characters is a chance of luck and not everyone is lucky enough to get those characters early on.

I think the game has overall changed for the better, eventhough there were a few changes I didn't like.

As a new player it would be much advised to play through most of the STORY content in order to build a decent team and obtain COIN to purchase more character slots (I would advise that you use COIN ONLY to purchase character slots because you dont get a lot and it costs more and more for ever 3rd or 4th slot obtained).

I hope this was insightful. If so please rate it as helpful.

Thanks and enjoy!

reviewText:
Honestly, after moving to my iPad and playing for over 8 months, I can tell you how good this game was and how bad this game is right now.

To start with, the old Matchmaking system is fairly easy to adapt to. You get to see opponents based on the points you have earned. The old system is really harsh for new players to handle at first but you will be able to handle it without no trouble later. Before the recent health changes and the nerf to mulitple heroes, most of the new released heroes (Starting from Iron Fist onwards) are completely broken to the point that destroys the fun out of the entire game.

After the Matchmaking changes, only new players can find easy and fair fights while transitioners and most of the players without full level roster could no longer climb up the rank. Some heroes were nerfed to a point which are uplayable. The developer promised a buff for Inivisible Woman a year ago and ended up nerfing her even harder.

With all the recent disappointment, many veteran players are leaving MPQ. So if you are a new player and finding this game extremely easy, good luck, because you will find the game so hard to play with once you decide to level up your heroes. So, make sure when you play as a new player, keep all your hero unlevel for the rest of your life. I promise you, it will make your game, very enjoyable indeed.

This review shall be my parting gift to the developer and ♥♥♥♥ YOU VERY MUCH!
(never in my life have I written a game review with a foul word, this time, I use it glady in your face)

reviewText:
This used to be a fun game and it still could be.  Unfortunately, the unmitigated greed on the part of the publishers has surfaced fully and without reservation in a recent patch where team healing was nerfed.

Healing used to be possible outside of PvE or PvP combat by going to the prologue and fighting a few battles with a healer and the damaged roster members.  Biff bam boom!  You're back to playing.  Now that healing is only temporary during that battle.  So, it's either wait 3+ hours for your team members to heal or pay for health packs.

The AI also cheats heavily, but I consider that more of a challenge to overcome than a reason to stop playing.

I already spent $40 (US) getting my roster space up to speed.  I refuse to spend more money on a game that is no longer fun for me.  This latest healing patch moved the game into the not fun" category.

If the patch notes and forum indicate the game has been fixed
date: I would be willing to pick the game back up.  Until then

reviewText: I cannot in good concise reccomend this one, I played it quite a bit on mobile, over 20+ hours in fact, and while the interface and art has survived to the desktop, it is stretched and not as crisp on my big screen. Other than that it is a well crafted match three with a unique enough mechanic to stand on its own as a really good game. But it has been hampered with the atrocious freemium model, where you pay for time or give them hundreds of dollars for an experience that is not worh more than 39.99 outright. It is a shame and I avoid the model like the plague, remove this caveat and let the game stand on its own and as it is it would be one of this gerations shining match three examples. As is I say avoid unless you like paying WAY more for games than they will ever be worth and unless you are fond of letting Publishing companies tell you how valuable your personal time is.

reviewText:
This is a stupid game.  The game itself is fine but the programming has destroyed it.  The adjustments have been so obviously tilted to make you spend more money, no one in their right mind will play this.  I love the game play but it has gotten so obvious that they are programming to help you if you spend a lot of money and not if you play the game.  You should just give them your credit card and let them suck all your cash out of your pocket while you sit with your thumb in your mouth.   The only thing these guys are doing is inspiring hate hate hate.  What are they thinking?

Listen, unless you spend a lot of money, the programming is designed to destroy your abilit to win.  The rewards for winning are just stupid.  Even with a decent set of characters, you absolutely should not lose challenges 9 times out of 10.  The only way this happens is if they assure that you will lose to inferior character sets according to how much money you have spent.  The rewards are irrational.  This is a joke.

You are a fool if you get started on this.  It is a collection game but the best way to collect anything is to buy it, not bother to play.  If you like paying $50 for a chance to get a virtual card, have a great time but this takes a good concept and destroys it.  Play the game.  You will love it.  Then you will hate those who are controlling the economic model.  If you start this game, you are throwing away your money.  Better to poke yourself in the eye with a pencil.   So, no, I don't recommend it at all.

reviewText:
I'm mainly basing this on the iOS version, but I downloaded and launched this game just to write this. I'd love to tell you how the PC version is different, but it keeps crashing every time I try and launch it! I understand the pictures are bigger. Game is the same, though

Let's start with the problems:

- Characters are deliberately unbalanced with a star system where more *** means more powerful.
- Higher-star characters are very difficult to unlock without spending money. Leveling them requires you to obtain them several times, so even if you get a rare character, good luck leveling it.
- Even if you spend money, you don't get a choice of your characters. They're randomized packs. However, spending money gives you a shot at more powerful characters.
- Even within a given star-rating balance is godawful. For example, Hawkeye and Black Widow are both 1-star characters. Hawkeye can do added damage, while Black Widow can stun an opposing character for 5 turns. I'll let you guess which regularly shows up on teams.
- Leveling up a character's powers fully requires you to basically unlock that character 11 to 16 times. This is in addition to grinding to level. You don't even get the choice of what powers you're leveling. It's random. If you get a power you've already maxed out, ha ha, ♥♥♥♥ you, so it can take a lot more than 11-16 unlocks.
- The single player campaign features huge jumps so that you have to grind in multiplayer to level up enough to progress, or... spend money. The grinding is not fun.
- Regularly the game has tournaments". Your competency in these tournaments will be determined by: character level

reviewText:
Solid gameplay and theme, but utimately it is a cash grab designed around forcing the user to pay money to avoid grinding some missions for rare curriencies and items.

You will be expected to play or grind for:
- The ability to recruit new heros to play with. You'll start with 3 (Iron Man, Storm and Black Widow) and you'll have one empty slot for a hero. After that you'll need to scronge up their pay currency to add an empty space to recruit any heros (including ones you earn that will expire and disappear if you don't get an empty space! Not to mention you'll earn recruit tokens which allow you to get characters for free, but not the empty space for free. If you don't have an empty space, they are WORTHLESS.
- Abilities and level ups. Character abilties are unlocked and leveled up after randomly earning comic book covers after missions. If you don't get the cover you need from a mission, you'll have to replay the SAME CONTENT to hope you earn it next time. And if you get 2 Hawkeye comics, but one is Classic Hawkeye and the other is Dark Avenger Hawkeye, those are two different characters and don't level up aside each other (not to mention they'll take up two character slots, which remember you're paying for!).

From what I saw, you'll grind up the pay currency by playing the semi-PVP battles. Much like the Marvel Facebook game, you'll fight AI-controlled player teams to place on a leaderboard for the shot at rewards. This isn't as much PVP as it is PVE where someone in the world happened to choose that team. Since this game allows people to gain a lot of power by paying money, the top spaces in the leaderboards (read: where you need to be for prizes) will be filled with 'wallet warriors': people who have amazing teams simply because they paid money. If you want to play this game and fork out minimal to zero cash, expect frustration. There ARE prizes for simply playing the PVP"
date: but you will need to devote a LOT of time to get the good items.\n\nFor example
recommended: winning a PVP match earns about 20-30 'Shield Points'. To get the pay currency for free
hoursPlayed: to unlock all the good stuff in the game without paying real money

reviewText: This game is like Candy Crush, in that you _can_ get through everything for free if you wait long enough, but unlike Candy Crush, where you could keep playing if you passed a stage, Marvel Puzzle Quest forces you to wait, no matter how good you are. Your heroes have HP which persist over stages, and it takes time for the heroes to recover HP. There are some stages where you can possibly go through without losing any health, but you'll get to stages where you just can't prevent damage, so if you want to continue, you'd need to wait for HP to regenerate, and then move on. Paying money is just for 'cheats'; extra EXP, other heroes, instant heals, etc. This game is pretty much unplayable if you're playing it for free.

reviewText:
Freemium hell.

The most frustrating match-3 game and the most egregious pay-to-win game I've ever played.

1. You get cards for new heroes faster than you get slots for them, so you're constantly throwing away heroes you don't have because there's no room. This seems really bad for a collectible game.
2. The designers seem to be adding more and more mechanics to boost the AI and make the game more laborious and frustrating to play.
2a. Healing goes away after each round, so it basically just helps the AI.
2b. Powers which hurt the enemy team and also your own team: These are poison for the player, but the AI can play them all day long
2c. The new specials seem to be free for the AI. Even easy matches can hurt your guys badly, which can't be healed away any more.
3. It seems like the developers are constantly nerfing useful powers, and not giving anything in return.
4. Quality of life issues never, ever get fixed
4a. Replaying rounds gives out booby prizes before you've collected all the rewards
4b. Can't see which enemy triggered a power
4c. Friending is done through Facebook only

The game seems to get more and more tedious and grindy after each patch. This is a really, thoroughly terrible game at this point, and for some reason it's only getting worse. Not recommended. Very much don't recommend giving it any money.

reviewText:
Do not fall for it!
Let me be clear: This game has great potential! It takes the formula of Puzzle Quest and improves on the combat and adds a lot of personality through the Marvel liscense!
That being said, what it comes down to ultimately, is a very cynical cash-grab.
The moneytization is tailor made to abuse the player in every way.
Let me explain:
There are two kinds of currency:
Violet Iso (regular)
Gold (premium)
Both can be bought with real cash.
Now, both drop after successful missions. But only once! Every reward is locked after one drow. Afterwards, doing missions (which can take up to half an hour) only reward 20 Iso (to give a comparison: a booster pack costs 500 Iso). So, you have to do a mission 25 times to get enough Iso to buy a booster.
Now, why not stick with the heroes you get and level them up?
Because the only way to level up heroes is by either spending premium currency directly OR getting more copies of the comics, the heroes originate from. And the latter can only be achieved by buying booster packs. Which only give a chance to obtain the right comic.
Furthermore, there is only one rarity category that can be bought with Iso-currency. The lowest, of course. And while you do have a chance to get a rare card from this category, the game is very honest about the fact that your chance is slim.
And don't forget that you need several copies of one comic to level your hero up.
This is a very blatant cash grab, made worse by the artwork. Yes, sadly, the artwork is very lackluster. The artist went for a semi-realistic style with dynamic posing. Sadly, the borders of different colours are very visible, which makes characters look unclean and bloaty and he had issues with contrasts and forshortening, making people look very strange and their clothes feel dodgy. (Take a look at Black Widow or Thor and you should see what I mean)
I repeat: Do not spend money on this game! It does not warrant it at all!

reviewText: Game is decent at best. The advantages the computer has is ridiculous. Constantly color starving you, massive cascades, and extra turns. It happens very often, one turn and the match is over for you. You can do this as well, but no where near the extent it happens for the computer. If you haven't invested much into the game, it is not worth it. It is a free game heavily designed as pay to win.\n\nThe game is tailored to have you spend money. Of course this is the main purpose of the game. Be it you spend money to try to get characters, to buy slots, to advance your characters to a point that you can compete, or just to heal so you can participate in events. The game is just not fun, it is tedious and repetitive. They constantly recycle events and try to force you to spend money in order to get the required characters to compete. If you are not a Marvel fan, it is probably best to avoid this game. 1 out of 10.

reviewText:
A Match-Three game in the genre of Candy Crush or Bejeweled, only with Marvel characters and micro transactions. There's a small storyline in there, but nothing exciting.

reviewText:
This should have been good.
Puzzle Quest is a solid concept, Marvel has a huge stable of interesting characters spanning decades of comics.
But... this fails on both sides.

Marvel side
The game is divided into chapters, each of them involves chasing after a new random villain. There is an overarching story about the Green Goblin being the leader of a new organization that replaces Shield which COULD have been interesting... but several chapters in that still hasn't gone anywhere and is more a convenient framing device to wheel various heroes and villains on and off stage.
In levels you're either picking your set of 3 heroes from your own stable or get backup from the fitting hero (e.g. Spiderman coming to your aid against Venom), but the selection of available heroes is limited in two ways.
Firstly, you can have a total of FOUR heroes to start out and the only way to increase this limit is to spend premium premium hero tokens which are hard to acquire without paying money. It's reasonable that within a chapter or two you're up to six hero slots, maybe eight if you only buy the slots. This means you have a very limited roster of heroes at the ready to develop and to be called into action if you need to change up your tactics.
The other problem is that the character roster seems very limited. You get the obvious main characters from recent Marvel films , the big-name mutants, the fantastic four and some random villains from what seems to be mostly the Dark Avengers. Ooh, Squirrel Girl too, which gives it some bonus points. However, there are plenty of characters that did not make the cut. I haven't seen Rogue or Phoenix yet, for example. Did we really need five different Storm, Black Widow, Iron Man and Thor variants instead of a more diverse roster? Don't get me wrong, I LIKE that I can pick which Storm I like best (both her look and skillset, though it would have been even better to pick these separately...), I'd just wished that there had been a few more lesser known characters.
Combined with the absolutely secondary and forgettable story it's just a total waste of the Marvel license.

Puzzle Quest side
At least this side should be easy to get right, right? Puzzle Quest 'inspired' games are plentiful and it's clear by now what works in free to play titles and what doesn't... turns out it apparently wasn't that easy.
The very core of the Puzzle Quest gameplay is still there. You take turns manipulating a match-3 square board in an attempt to gather resources and defeat the enemy. Puzzle Quest was strictly a one versus one system, but in this game each side can consist of up to 3 characters.
Each character has up to three skills, each tied to a colour on the board, and an attack value for each colour that determines the damage it does to the targeted enemy when making a match with it. Fortunately there is no need to switch an 'active character' or anything to maximize your damage. So if you brought Lady Thor and Gamora and match yellow tiles then the game just looks up which character would deal the most damage (in this case Thor) and have that character attack. Which character attacks based on the various colours is also indicated on the stones in case this is relevant for any of the active skills in the battle (which rarely happens).
This bit is solid. It suffers from some of the same randomness that plagues this type of game in almost every iteration, where the enemy just happens to luck into a huge combo that drops into place from the top of the screen as tiles get destroyed, but it's hard to fault this particular game for that.
What it DOES do wrong is that there are way too many different colours on the board. There are SIX different colours of mana to gather and use for skills and a seventh block type with the team up tokens (that allow for one-shot special attacks that aren't as impressive as they sound). The original puzzle quest had 4 mana colours, damage tiles, experience tiles and coin tiles for a total of seven as well, so you'd think that'd be okay but it tends to fall flat. Going back to the Thor example (she was the rarest character I managed to get and is awesome), she has a cool skill that deals damage to the entire enemy team but it needs 12 yellow mana (or AP as the game calls it). The problem is that there are so many different colours that it's hard to specifically try to gather a single colour (or even two colours to focus on...). It seems more about just making matches than gathering specific mana types.

The above would be an okay if imperfect implementation of the puzzle quest side of things... but of course we have to remember that this is a free to play game, so there have to be things in place to limit what you can do so that you either grind for it cough up some money.
Prospective players will be happy to hear that there is no energy mechanic in this game... then immediately disappointed again when I explain that damage the heroes receive in a game is persistent and then needs time to heal (my Thor needed several hours after being knocked out). You can start games with injured heroes, but it obviously sets you at a disadvantage. Medkits can be used to instantly heal a hero (outside of battle), but they are in short supply. Beyond the 10 you start the game with I've found ONE from a one-time mission reward. Of course a solution is to just switch to other heroes until your preferred ones are healed, but as I mentioned above, you have very limited roster space available so the game really wants you to focus on single heroes.

Which brings me to the next big point, which is hero progression. Remember how in Puzzle Quest you got experience points from fights like in an RPG? Well, this isn't like that at all. Winning a game gets your heroes nothing, but you as the player receive some ISO-8, a mutation drug that might have a justification for being there in the later part of the plot, it's just sort of explained and then dropped entirely at the start. The idea is that you spend this ISO-8 to power up your heroes, and it's easy to see this as a communal experience point pool... except that it doesn't get filled very often.
Every mission you play gives you a few hundred ISO-8 for the first time you complete it and might also have another batch in its drop table of random one-time rewards, which means that the total amount of ISO-8 is LIMITED. Sure, you can buy more with real money or by selling off some of your spare heroes, but that kind of goes against the point.

Using ISO-8 to level up your hero increases its life and the damage dealt by matching specific tiles, but only up to the hero's current level cap. This limit can be extended 12 times by sacrificing a duplicate card, or almost duplicate anyway. You see, each of the heroes you receive or buy will only have one of its three skills randomly assigned to it. So Thor can either hit the enemy with his hammer, gather a storm cloud (spawning a bunch of yellow tiles on the field) or call the lightning down (using up that yellow AP the previous skill got you), but only ONE of those things until you find another copy of that hero.
And before you get your hopes up, there are no places to farm this stuff. You'll be stuck spending ISO-8 or hero tokens (you know, those hard-limited currencies I was complaining about earlier?) to get a random hero. A duplicate hero that has a skill you already have unlocked can be used to develop that skill, making it more effective and sometimes making it do slightly more things (e.g. more tiles when gathering storm clouds). Upgrading skills can also be done directly with hero tokens, getting new skills can not. To have a 'perfect' character you'll need 3 cards with 3 different skill slots and a ton of money OR 13 cards, divided in groups of 3-5 over the 3 skills.
Which means that even if you pay, you'll need a ton of luck to get what you want which is just frustrating.

Bad mechanics, poor story. Don't play

reviewText:
Very simplistic game that doesn't even remotely feature the number of many elements that could be found in the original Puzzle Quest. Easily-accessible PvP and tournaments seemed like a nice idea, but you are expected to grind a lot of levels for your super heroes team before you can be competitive, instead of just trying and enjoying it.

Almost every additional feature requires you to pay money. Need more slots for heroes? Buy them. Need healing items? Better spend some money. Need to level up and get new skills? The fees are due! All of this can be paid with gold, which is the in-game currency, but you're gonna need a lot of it.

Currently the game is a glorified shadow of Puzzle Quest with some Marvel heroes and a rather silly plot.

reviewText:
While I still play this game, and (kind of) enjoy it, I cannot recommend it at this point.  The degree to which the developer ignores their players is crazy.  Cheating is rampant and destroying the reward structure of the game. Cheaters are regularly reported, but action is extremely slow to come, if it ever does. (Literally months between initial reports of a player/alliance cheating and any action.)

Additionally, the developer doesn't seem to play test characters or changes to characters, or changes to the structures of their events, before implementing them.  It's like they don't really know what they want to do with the game, so just do things.  The game keeps getting imbalanced in new and frustrating ways.

I've spent around $40 on this free-to-play game, but likely won't spend another dime unless the developer makes substantial improvements in how they treat their players.  (IE- don't make it a cash grab, actually respect your customers.)

reviewText:
A lot of people say this game is Pay to Win, but it's a bit misleading. Sure, if you're willing to drop trucktons of money into the game, you'll get access to stuff a lot faster than you would normally, but that holds true for nearly every single free to play game. I personally don't consider this a Pay to Win game.
I'm writing this review to shed some light on this. To do so, I'll go into some further depth of how the resources and the game works. Beware, as there will be a lot of things I touch upon here. I'll leave a short summary at the bottom.

You have two main resources in this game - ISO-8 and Hero Points.
ISO-8 is primarily used to level up your characters and can be obtained easily and reguilarily, sometimes in very large quantities. Think of it as your common resource, you'll always need more and it is also the most available.

Hero Points are much less common. Hero Points are used for a number of things, and could be compared to a premium resource, if you will. It is used to increase the maximum amount of characters you can have at any given time aswell as purchasing new characters and their powers. Hero Points can also be used to purchase additional Health Packs and to Shield yourself in PvP Events (more on both later).
It is available in limited supply from story missions - often enough to get you started - but the main source of Hero Points tend to be from the events that happen regularily. Events work similiar to the main storyline missions and the main PvP, except they have a set time limit. After the time is up for any event, you will receive rewards based on your placements in the rankings - Rewards consist of a combination of specific Covers (unlocks characters or upgrades their powers), Booster packs (contains random Covers), Hero Points and ISO-8. Apart from the rewards you get for your ranking, there are also progression rewards in most events that reward you at set intervals with ISO-8, Hero Points, Covers or Boosters.

Next I'll go into health packs. Normally as your characters take damage in battle, they will slowly regenerate that health back (real-time) when they are not in battle. If a character is downed (in-game definition of a character running out of health) in battle, they also need a certain amount of time to recover from that on top of the time to regenerate their health. However, you can use Health Packs to instantly revive and fully heal any character. Health Packs naturally regenerate up to a stock of 5, but you can purchase additional health packs for Hero Points. You are also relatively regularily awarded Health Packs from missions, daily rewards and progression rewards.

Next up we have Shields. Normally in PvP Events, you lose/gain points in the event whenever you are attacked by another player. Shields can be purchased with Hero Points to protect you from point loss due to other players attacking you for a limited time - I do not know if it also disables points gains from defensive victories. Attacking any player while a shield is active will prematurely end the effect.

Last but not least are combat boosts. These are regularily and randomly dropped after any kind of combat, as mission drops aswell as progression rewards and come in different flavors. They are generally simple, providing small bonuses to specific areas - more damage or starting AP for powers (AP is generated by matching colored tiles), though there are much larger bonuses available that are far more rare (+150% damage vs specific kinds of enemies). You can purchase more of these bonuses for ISO-8 (and possibly Hero Points, I do not know since I haven't used any rare boosts).
Personally I very rarely use boosts, I have only been using a few in some of the more difficult PvE battles, and they are by no means necessary to stay competetive.

Covers are generally what you are ultimately after. They unlock the character in question when you obtain your first one and either unlocks or increases levels of their powers with further ones. They come in four rarities shown by stars, from 1-star covers to 4-star covers. They are obtained regularily, most commonly from Boosters which in turned are awarded as mission rewards, progress rewards, event prizes and a few other sources. Your covers determine the strength of your characters' powers, but most importantly determine the maximum level you can level your character up to. The maximum level possible for a character is based on their rarity and actually leveling up characters uses ISO-8.
Boosters will give you a random cover, with a minimum rarity based on what kind of booster it is. There are two generic boosters that can give you pretty much any character in the game, but there are regularily specialized" boosters available during events that contain one cover randomly chosen from a specific poll of characters
date: usually characters involved or powered up during the event. You can also purchase additional boosters in the in-game store for ISO-8 (only the basic booster) or Hero Points.\nEvents prizes and progress rewards will often grant you specific character covers. Event prizes tend to be covers ranging from 2- to 4-star covers
recommended: depending on your final rank (along with Hero Points and ISO-8)
hoursPlayed:
while progress rewards can reward you with anything from 1- to 4-star covers  (though 4-star cover progression rewards are usually practically impossible to reach within the timeframe of an event).


In short
voteText: these resources are all either awarded regularily no matter what area of the game you play (Health Packs
helpfulPercent: Boosts and ISO-8) or regularily as rewards in event prizes and progression (Hero Points
votesHelpful: ISO-8
votesTotal: Covers
votesFunny: Boosts and Boosters). The only exceptions are Shields
commentsCount: but they are not much of a resource to begin with.\n\nI have spent a lot of time on this game

column19: a 2-star booster) aswell as a reasonable amount of progression rewards. You never *need* Shields in PvP events to get a good placement

reviewText:
Match 3, Marvel, but.... Microtransactions.

The game's mechanics of a match-3 to initiate fights is far from new anymore - but its complicated by the need to heal" injured combatants either by waiting or buying health packs.

That's the first clue.

reviewText:
<<< Matching colors addict - Updated as of May 15, 2016 - Some new and cool changes in the last few months! (read near the bottom of the review for info on them)

If you have been reading negative reviews in regards to P2W (pay 2 win) then they are biased. This game is free but real fans will spend money on it because they want to collect as many characters as they can and level them up fully. If you don't put effort into this game then you won't get too far and you will be discouraged. It takes patience and time to get anywhere. For fans and people who enjoy this type of build up with RPG elements this game is great! It gives you something to check everyday and play for a short while.

Any fan of the Marvel Universe should get this game, especially since it is free. Players who pay will have an advantage in the sense that they can level up their character cards faster and buy more slots to recruit new characters, but once you get a bit further you can compete in daily competitions/leaderboards to win new characters and powers, crystals for levelling and gold coins for buying new character cards and extra slots.

pros - A good chillin game, just need a mouse
- Made for fans of Marvel (obviously) and matching puzzle games with RPG elements
- Lots of super heroes and villians to collect ranging from one star* to four stars**** and now      with the new update new five star***** characters are available that can be levelled up to 450!
- A lot of strategy is required if you want to win difficult matches against higher level enemies.
- Collectable/usable power-ups and character power cards (usable once in a battle)!
- You can join or create an alliance and there are competition and leaderboards for your crew to compete in for prizes like new character cards, coins, crystal and 2-3 star cards from either the vault which is a random card generator that you stop yourself or a hero card that gives u a random 2-4 star character.
- Light on the PC
- Developers are active always updating the game, adding new characters periodically and creating new competitions and battles daily.

cons - Addictive
- If you are color blind you might want to avoid this game
- Random character card received when purchasing new cards
- You will get many doubles which you can sell...but it can get annoying.

Back to pros
- UPDATE! - You can now max out your character level and pay an extra amount of crystal to make the maxed out character a legend. This allows you to use extra cards (that before would be useless and sold for crystal) to continue leveling up your character. One level per character card. Every level gives you a reward as well. like Command points, crystals, other character cards and coins.
- Command points are used to obtain **** 4 and ***** 5 star character cards. 20 for classic and 25 for modern. These command points are also used for upgrading characters if one can never find the one card they need for one of their characters.

Overall score: 8.0/10
Chance of becoming an addict (playing it daily) score: 7.0/10

Update: Marvel Puzzle Quest has changed a lot since I wrote this review. Mostly for the worse. While I do still enjoy playing the game it is largely because I already had a decent force before a lot of the changes were made. The company repeatedly ignores their fan base and makes changes that make the game increasingly hard to play without paying and really expensive if you do pay. I'm going to list the notable changes since this review was originally posted.

The Good:
1. The ever increasing roster size keeps collecting covers interesting and gives reason to come back to the game.
2. PvP seasons: The company recently introduced PvP seasons. These are month long event that keep track of players as they partake in PvP events. The top rated players get fantastic rewards.

The Bad:
1. Shields: In Marvel Puzzle Quest PvP events run on a points system. At first glance it is simple and  fair. In fact it used to be fair but shields have all but ruined the accessability. For every round you win you gain points. If you lose a round you lose points. This is fine. Being that PvP is actually Player vs. AI player people must be able to challenge computer versions of other players. When a computer version of yourself wins or loses you also gain/lose points according. This has always been annoying but for the most part fair. However, shields allow a player to spend a decent sum of money in order to protect themselves from point loss. In otherwords free players quickly lose points from their AI losing but they can't make those who pay lose any points. This makes it very hard for free players especially when first starting off.
2.Gold Characters: Gold characters are enhanced versions of other characters. This essentially means the developers got lazy and wanted to release a new character but didn't feel like designing new character powers. While that alone is annoying it is tolerable. What isn't tolerable is taking a character and nerfing him because he is overpowered" and then release a stronger version of the character right after. For anyone who joined late and doesn't know this is exactly what they did with Thor.
3. Boost Changes: Boosts were an easy way to allow free players to stand a fighting chance. A player could buy boosts with Iso(in game currency) in order to assist a strategy using what are otherwise weak characters. However
votesHelpful: boosts have changed so that in order to buy the useful ones you must spend hero points(premium currency).\n4. Healing Changes: In Marvel Puzzle Quest you have always needed to wait for your characters to heal after battle. How long you have to wait varies depending on character level. You have also always been able to pay in order to heal instantly. While this has always given paying members an advantage
votesTotal: it wasn't outrageous because within a couple hours your characters would heal. However
votesFunny:
the company has recently made it take longer for heroes to heal making the game even harder to play for free.

The Ugly:
1. Pay to Enter Tournaments: These are occasional tournaments that have an entry fee. The prizes to be won in said tournaments are outstanding. The winner gets one of every cover in the game. While I like the idea of large tournaments that have a little risk to them I don't like how these particular tournaments are set up. I'm fine with an entry fee but the fee should be in iso. I personally think there should be an entry fee somewhere along the lines of 5000-10000 iso. This is a decent amount of currency so there is a big risk for the players but it is entirely in-game currency so it is accessable to everyone if they are willing to save up for a while. Unfortunately the tournament entry fee is in hero points
commentsCount: so it once again favors those who pay fairly significantly.\n2. Alliances: Alliances
column16: are this games version of a clan. All events have alliance rankings in addition to individual rankings. All members of the top ranked alliances get prizes. Alliances had the potential to be a great addition to the game. having a community to play with and talk to as well as getting additional prizes for doing so is fantastic. Where the game went wrong is in Alliance sizes. An Alliance starts with 5 player slots. However
column17: the alliance leader has the option to buy additional slots up to 20. Of course to buy these slots you have to spend Hero points. So only the alliances who pay ever win events because they have a larger player base. Adding an additional slot to a guild isn't cheap either; additional slot cost as much expanding you roster size post 20 heroes.\n\nSo would I recommend this game now? Maybe
column18: it is really hard to say at this moment due to the fact that I started out so early. I do believe it is possible to do decently well while being a free player but I am rather biased because I already had a large army. Furthermore
column19: at the rate which D3/Demiurge are ruining the game within a month it will likely be totally inaccessable to any new free players and possibly even veteran free players."

reviewText:
Ok so Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign. A somewhat port from a IOS game. And it is notable. Few options, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ UI, some bad graphics and animations. Lacking even the basic options, like turning off combat animations. Which can become extremely repetetive after a short time, due to the fact that each hero can have a max of 3 skills.
The gameplay combine the Puzzle Quest series with Marvel universe.  If you are a fan of the puzzle quest series or marvel universe, its worth giving a shot.
The free to play model they use in this game is really weird and somewhat counterproductive. The worst part being that your heroes does not heal instantly after a match. Instead they heal over time. Having a lvl 50 Iron Mand die ---> wait 3hours.
I guess the idea is to have people buy health packs to resurrect/heal the heroes.

Summary
+ addictive gameplay
+ licensed superheroes from Marvel Universe
+ loads of weekly/daily/hourly tournaments where you compete with other peoples heroes for prizes
+ long and challenging campaign
+ dont have to invest any money to be able to do well ingame

- Bad UI, graphics, animation
- Alot of our favourite Marvel superheroes is not in the game
- Impending shadow of a poor free to play model
- Weird gamechoices regarding leveling of powers, herolevel and healing
- Bad AI (will use skills whenever they have enough resources, even tho it only hurts them)

I still recommend the game to fans of puzzlequestish games, and fans of marvel. Game is very timeconsuming and I would totally play it on an IOS while taking a ♥♥♥♥. Just dont expect anything more.

reviewText:
Steam says I have more than 2000 hours in the game, but the truth is it is mostly running on the background. I'd say 500 hours is much closer to reality.

Here is what you need to know about the game. It is a 3vs3 match where you bring a team of heroes/villains and try to win by making use of their abilities. You use them by spending the required resources (AP) which you get when you match tiles. The characters are divided in 4 tiers (1* - 4*) with only the 3* and very few of the 2* being useful at the moment. Most characters have 3 abilities, but there are some with only 2 because the developers have left them incomplete for months. The abilities can gain levels by buying or winning covers. The stats of the characters and the effectiveness of their abilities are increased as you level them with the use of ISO-8, an in-game currency used solely for leveling characters and buying boosts you can use in matches. The second currency is called HP (Hero Points) and is used to increase the size of your roster and to level abilities without the use of covers.

The good: Fast game / doesn't require too much thinking which makes it ideal for short gaming bursts / you get to use your favorite heroes / very simple rules.

The bad: Several incomplete characters with no plan to finish them in the near future / a turn from F2P to P2P since March 2014 / Inconvenient event end times for Europeans / success depends heavily on playing close the end of an event / several exploits are reported which allow cheaters to roam free in the game / market prices for in-game currency are the worst I have seen in a game.

Advices:
1. Use HP only to buy roster slots. At least until you have 30-35 slots. Never buy tokens (they give random covers). The % to get a specific 3* hero is less than 1% in most cases. You have better results if you level the abilities directly with HP.
2. Never use ISO-8 to buy 1* tokens. You will need it to level your heroes and it will always, ALWAYS be in short supply.
3. Always take part in Lightning Rounds since they are the most efficient source of ISO. Try to get to 100 points.
4. Don't max a 3* hero unless you have a diverse roster with at least 3-4 more heroes with levels 85+. When you do, the levels of the teams you fight will also increase a lot.

Epilogue: I will not tell how to spend your money, but you have to know that the game has made a turn into a more P2P model after March 2014. The changes in late June change how healing works in the game and restricts your ability to play since there is practically no way to heal heroes unless they have an innate regeneration ability. Heroes heal over time, but with most of them taking 2-4 hours to fully heal. healing packs are your only alternative and they cost HP which is relatively rare. The market prices are ridiculously unreasonable. To fully level a 3* hero you will need ~170k ISO which costs ~$300. The game is quite addictive so be warned. I would advice against letting young children play with it. I bet they can find better things to do and you should encourage them to spend their time doing something more creative. So do I recommend this game? After the changes in the last 2-3 months, I do not.

reviewText:
Possibly one of the most brutal micro-transaction games I've ever encountered. Hero points are the real money to game currency that is required for everything from character space, leveling up your powers, entry into some game events, character boosts for individual battles, and having a better chance at new characters above a one star rating.

Core game is great if you enjoyed Puzzle Quests games in the past. Enjoyment of the core game, however, will not overcome how terrible the dev team is for this game. In addition to microtransaction hell, content is frequently untested/broken. Characters are nerfed without warning and are almost never buffed. No refunds are given to your Hero Points/Iso-8 costs. You must sell them at a 50% loss or deal with it.   New content buffs NPCs to over level 200 which makes taking them down near impossible without purchasing major boosts to up your team's damage and action points.  I will also note that most of your team fully maxed out will have a level cap significantly under 200 unless you're willing to splurge tons of real cash on acquiring four star characters.

Their dev teams also publically taunt their players and customers in their forums. Not in a reasonable and fun way (ie. Cloaker quotes in Payday 2) but rather telling players to go ahead and rate their game negatively and spread poor word of mouth. Signed, sealed and accepted mother ♥♥♥♥ers!

reviewText:
Short version: Stay away.

Longer version:
Gameplay is fun but very, very shallow. Content, in the form of characters to burn resources chasing, is continually expanding, while new story content or gameplay expansion remian few and far between. It's extremely repetitive and grindy.

This game launched in an anemic and hilariously unbalanced form, and has come a long way in 2 years. It's growing and being proted to consoles. Great.

It does still have a fun tightknit community that can be accessed via the dev's forum. That's the best thing about the game, the other people playing it, not the game itself. Hmmm.

It is probably the prettiest match-3 game around .... that isn't saying much. The game mechanics, after 2 years of bolt-ons, are held together by baling wire. Unintended results abound and are discovered the hard way by players.

Play it casually for awhile and then move on. God help you if you allow it to become a habit. (See those hours logged? There but for the grace of the gods go you.)

The worst is the dev's inept attempts at communication. Spectacularly bad. Here is a great example ...

This week is the game's 2-year anniversary. It centers on a new event, a battle against Galactus. The blance of the event is laughably out of whack; the ONLY way to win is to make use of exploits (which the inept developer failed to catch ...). Other events running concurrently are suffering from various bugs, and the anniversary rewards have been found to be WORSE than the normal in-game rewards (Happy anniversary!)

After the event runs for a day, and the online community is thoroughly hacked off, the producer posts the below. Judge it for yourself.
_____________________
Hey all,

Wanted to share a few things about how Galactus works and what we're expecting versus what we're seeing.

To start, it seems like a lot of people are on a basic disconnect here, looking at the boss battle similar to how Ultron ran in terms of how things work. Meaning that Ultron should be going down pretty regularly. He's powerful, but his real power lies in the fact that killing his body doesn't stop him. You need to crush every one of his drones and main bodies to win. So winning rounds is a pretty regular occurrence. Game-wise, what this means is that players won fairly easily against Ultron and took their lumps against the drones. The stopping timer there was health packs based on when the drones finally wore you down. What this also meant is that the higher end Alliances would chew through the entire Event in about 12 hours and let it kinda sit for 3 days.

Galactus is different. The minion" fights against the villains are relatively simple. They're there as minor hazards but relatively easily winnable. Galactus on the other hand is a massive threat. He's not going to be stopped by gnats. Iron Fist punching him in the toe isn't very painful. So he gets bored and swats them away. In game terms
date: this means that players are going to be beaten. Winning a round against Galactus is an achievement. You're supposed to lose. Every time you do
recommended: you're still chipping away at his life. It's an exercise in damage in aggregate. Over the 3.5 days
hoursPlayed: hitting him over and over to finally bring down the big bad is somewhat slow
voteText: but certainly effective.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: most of the higher end Alliances are in Round 6 or knocking on the door to Round 7. Which is actually slightly faster than we were expecting people to get just based on the math. So everyone's doing pretty darned well in terms of progression. There are some teams rockin' the Winfinite
votesHelpful: other teams that are pushing through with some interesting strategies (who woulda thought OBW would be a rock star against Galactus?). Not many Alliances are getting anywhere near full clears. Which is actually intended. You're supposed to lose your Health Packs on Galactus
votesTotal: rather than against the minions like on Ultron. It's also why we changed up the play method for this round too so that it's not just a flip flop between Ultron and minions till you win. There's a set number of times you can hit Galactus before you need to take a break to let minions refresh. That break means that you have plenty of times for Galactus drained Packs to refresh while you can go in and get some Black Vortex in. Or play Simulator (up soon). Or get your Devil Dino on when that starts up. It's a different design than the rush of Ultron where that was pretty much all players did while it was open.\n\nLong story short

reviewText:
Game has become a negative posterchild for pay to win. Before people who didn't spent any or just some money for slots etc. had a fighting chance. And even more importantly, they had some time to enjoy the game. Now they nerfed healing, so most Characters with healing skills get their healing only temporarily. Before, you could play 1-2 hours w/o a problem w/o having to use so called health packs.

Now, w/o proper healing, after you used your 5 free healthpacks per day, which can easily happen after 2-3 games, as EACH hero (you can use 3 heroes at a time) needs to get healed with one pack. So after 3 games (maybe 10 minutes) you can easily run out of health packs and that was it for the day as it takes hours for the healthpacks to replenish. Most people won't have the time play for 10-20 minutes every 5 or so hours, because they work and basically have a life.

If you wanted, like I did before, enjoy an hour or the occasional 2 hours on the couch, playing Dark Reign, you are now out of luck. After 30 minutes tops you run out of health packs and heroes to play. And guess how you only (reliably) get them back? Right, by purchasing them with real money. reviewText:
It's a pretty generic match-3 puzzle game, which I have no problem with - games like that can be (and often are) quite fun. The problem is that the entire game is clearly pay-to-win from the start and microtransactioned out the butt.

Want to level up your hero? ...you can, eventually, if you get the right random drop... or you can pay to level them up. Your hero is injured? Well, you can go play something else for a few hours as you wait for him to eventually heal... or you can buy heals for any injured heroes.

If you don't mind microtransactions... I still can't recommend it. There are plenty of games you could be spending your tiny bits of cash on that are way more fun than a simple match-3 game.

reviewText:
Cons outweigh pros by FAR
Too many things about this game make it painfully frustrating and totally not worth playing.

The worst thing is how often I'm forced to sit back and watch uncountable cascades or other nonsense because the tile drops are not random. The algorithm they use not only identifies the chosen characters in order to set tiles on the board but also identifies how many of which tiles are on the board before selecting which tiles to drop after a match. Watching which tiles drop a few times lets you quickly begin to predict which tiles are likely to drop next. Being able to predict should help your strategies but, as you quickly learn, it does not.

Equivalently to this problem, you are forced to play on the developers terms:

You must endlessly grind the same match to get 1/4 rewards.

You must begin a fight just to view inventory of boosts AND you must manually de-select the boosts from a previous fight.

When you gain hero tokens you must decide whether to open the token (for an incredibly rare chance to gain something you actually want) or keep the unopened token indefinitely. Once you open the token you must then choose whether to sell the hero for ISO, swap the hero for another hero already on your roster (if you don't have enough Hero Points to open a slot for them), or let the hero expire and receive nothing.

On mobile devices, you're forced to endure 100+MB updates every other week. Which brings up another crucial point: almost every update adds a new character. Pretty cool, right? Keeps things dynamic by adding fresh meat. Well, aside from EVERY update causing new bugs (oh, crashes cause an infuriating problem I'll get to next), at the beginning, the first 4 slots to add new characters to your roster are free. However, as you keep adding characters, the cost of the slots keep going up. Here's what they cost after the first 4:

Roster Slot        Hero Pts                5        25                10        200                24        300                29        400                37        500                45        600                53        700                61        800                69        900                77+        1000
It's like the devs punish you for collecting a full roster. How does this make any sense? Meanwhile, if you're enough of a sucker to throw hundreds of dollars at these developers, you must still be able to work ... uhh play(?) on the game's schedule just to compete with anyone for the rewards you want... but if you've got that kind of time & money to throw at one single fremium game, what rewards do you need that you couldn't buy outright? Oh, that's right--you can't. There are only 2 things you can definitively buy (which are both outrageously priced): ISO and Hero Points.

Game Crashes: Many poorly programmed games are prone to crashes and this one is no exception but D3 adds some twists to this back-alley gut-stabbing. The game may randomly crash while you are in the middle of a match and that's not the worst part. When the crash occurs, the game treats your sudden exit as if you have chosen to retreat which damages your team! Forget that retreat damage is asinine to begin with but now devs add 'injury' to insult by doing nothing about game crash damage. Want to re-initiate the game and try to replay the match with your ideally chosen team? Tough luck! They're either dead or half dead!

There is a whole other side of this 'game' which allows players to 'fight' each other (you only play against A.I. on any part of the game) that I won't go into. I've played it only enough to realize how utterly futile it is. If you check out the D3Go forums you'll see the extent of frustration that people have for the multitude of flaws in 'versus' mode.

Beyond all that, I see many people rate it high then say It's great BUT..." or recommend it and say it's addicting as though being an addict is a good thing.

If I could
date: I would only recommend this title to people I hate."

reviewText:
Bottom line: Very slow and grindy from the get-go.

Don't get me wrong I know exactly what I'm in for when I download something with the tag free to play". I know that eventually I will come to point in the game where the progress slows down and I have to decide whether to commit my time or my money. I do not expect every f2p game to be PoE or DOTA2. But the thing that disappointed me with this game was how soon I got to that point.

In my experience these sorts of free to play games
recommended: tend to be pretty fast paced at first to get you hooked and learn the ropes. Then as the pace of progression gradually slows down you can start to really appreciate and understand what you can accomplish long term
hoursPlayed:
either through play or through paying. But Marvel Puzzle quest sort of just gives you one semi-fast prologue chapter and then says "now we grind".

I haven't even beaten the second prologue chapter yet and my best character (Iron-man) takes over an hour in real time to heal up to full health if he’s downed. The battles even against normal goons take a long time now. Even if the battle isn't hard they usually damage my heroes so much that I can't use them for a good while. And the reward for beating them are sometimes just these consumable boosts that do not progress your characters in any way which makes it feel like you won nothing for such a long battle.

My most dominating thought is "if it's this grindy in the prologue how bad will it be when I actually get to play the main PVE/PVP modes?" I don't know

Long story short:

This was a viable puzzle game.  While it had some issues, these were not too severe.
