Before the most recent patch, this was probably the worst part of the game as there are only so many times you can defeat the same five characters repeatedly.

Then the healing nerf hit.

D3, in a fit of absolute greed and the worst show of judgement, decided to patch the game so that any and all healing buffs were now False healing" in order to force the player to buy more healing packs in order to continue to play past two or three matches.  This nerf not only crippled the healing characters
date: it has made characters such as Sentry unplayable.  By eliminating the low-level hot dog stand healing

hoursPlayed: there are better Free-to-Play or even match-3 puzzle games to invest your time in than this misuse of the Marvel License."

reviewText:
You'll see plenty of reviews that tackle what the developers have done to absolutely bend over their once-loyal players. But, I'll still add my voice to that camp.

The game starts out deceptively fair for a Free-to-Play. But I've spent money because I wanted to support it, I absolutely love match-3 puzzle games, and MPQ began very strong. I expected to get more out of my real money and time invested. But in the end, the microtransactions carry some of the most ludicrous price tags I've ever seen. Especially once you realize how shafted you are. If you max out a hero's level capacity (Each hero has a maximum level directly proportional to its rarity) you can spend ISO (a f2p resource earned from playing) to level them once the right number of 'covers' (item drops that level up 1 of 3 abilities a hero has) has been obtained.

The developers are just NOT providing the level of return investment quality in their microtransactions. And they know it. You have to spend a STAGGERING amount of money or a nigh-impossible amount of game time to acquire competitive max-level high rarity heroes. Look at my total time played. I legitimately have 3 maxed out uncommon heroes and a handful of level 15-50 uncommon and rares. When I look at the amount of hours invested, I'm not upset. It's a great distraction at my relatively low-demanding job, but at the same time, I don't feel the devs have spent nearly as much time developing meaningful addons, GRAPHICAL IMPROVEMENTS (ffs this game is a goldmine) or a truly diverse lineup of Marvel originals.

All in all, give it a try if you like puzzle games, but honestly, there are more rewarding ones out there. I'm turning my back on it and putting my disposable income on something else.

reviewText: I wanted to like this game.  Puzzle Quest is one of my favorite time killers, and this borrows heavily from that game and adds a neat three on three dimension that I found cool.  But the leveling up system is stupidly complicated and based on a degree of luck that sucks all the fun out of it.  You're HP is not restored to full power after each match, which means you either have to wait around half the day for it to regenerate or you can purchase the in-game currency that will let you restore it immediately.  After getting frustrated as hell with MPQ: DR for a couple of weeks, I deleted it from my library.  Save yourself the trouble and don't bother trying it.  Go buy the sequel to Puzzle Quest instead, or maybe Galactrix.  Don't get sucked in just because it features Marvel superheroes.

reviewText:
Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign Review

A game titled Marvel Puzzle Quest has a lot to live to up to. Not for the Marvel part, but instead due to the deserved respect and love that Puzzle Quest received for successfully creating a hybrid RPG/Bejeweled-style match-three game. Marvel Puzzle Quest has taken the idea of a puzzle game with with a strategic/role-playing element overlay, and turned it into an intricately crafted, remarkably deep experience.

In Marvel Puzzle Quest, you control three superheroes who fight against up to three other supervillains/heroes (or goons, in some of the plot missions). When matched, the six colors of gems on the board grant energy that can be used for special moves, like purple matches helping Hawkeye use “Take Aim,” a skill that ensures a critical hit. Every match also serves as an attack, but the amount of damage depends on individual characters' affinity with the color – which also gives combo attacks a nice superhero fight feel to them, where Iron Man lands a punch and then Black Widow jumps in. Meanwhile, skills that offer buffs to defense/strength, or do damage over time, manifest as changes to tiles on the board, which can be matched and eliminated. Thus, the board becomes amazingly tactical – there are up to half a dozen potential considerations beyond “best match” at any given point.

Unfortunately the game ended up being a pay to win game with overpriced micro-transactions.

reviewText:
The game concept is very fun and interesting. There are many events happening all the time. It would have a lot of potential if not for...

- Money grab tactics to progress. Forced to spend Hero Points (hard to earn unless you spend money) just to buy slots to have +1 character. These slots get more expensive with each few slots you buy, until it gets out of hand expensive.
- If you want to play for free and win some good characters and Hero Points, you need to schedule your life around the game's events starting and ending time. (EDIT: this seems to have been addressed.)
- PvP system is implemented in a way that forces you spend to spend Hero Points to be competitive.
- The game seems to progress nicely in the beginning until you hit several deadends which will tempt you to spend money.

Try it out if you wish, DON'T spend money at all until you played for at least 2 or 3 months. You will regret it. It has potential, if you don't mind spending money on a game every week and have no real life commitments, this may be a game for you.

reviewText:
Three months ago when I started this game, I loved playing it. I truly enjoy three-match puzzles and this also introduced me better to the Marvel universe. There are regular events with witty dialogue and the more I played, the more I felt rewarded.

Then I had two characters leveled to 85 (the current max level at the time for Thor and Storm) and that's when hell was unleashed. Oh dear.

Even though there is PVP in the game, you never play against an actual person. Instead their three characters are controlled by the computer. And since the computer is dreadful at this game, the only way the computer can win is by having victory magically handed to them. Every single day I see the exact same cheating tactics and that is what makes me angry about the gameplay. The opponents gets everything they need for their abilities magically apearing on the top row, they get deadly cascades of nodes dropping endlessly and I have seen them clear one row only to have it replaced completely with nodes of a color they need.

I finally had enough of this game. I don't enjoy playing a game where victory is handed to the opponent, when there obviously was no nodes to ensure their victory when I ended my turn.

2015 update
One year after writing the review originally, I decided to see if things have changed for the better. Some things are better, while others have the exact problems as last year.

Improvements- Many new heroes. Easier to collect some heroes that were concidered rare" last time I was playing.
- Updated abilities for older characters
date:
making some of them better to use.
- City nodes are replaced with team-up nodes. You have three team up cards (which can be given to you by your alliance and found randomly) that can be used with team up points. These are far better than the city nodes and have actually helped me win some games.
- A daily quest which gives you a chance to get rare heroes or plenty of resources.

Things that still are flawed
Opponents still cheats horribly. Anytime I try to play anything that isn't 50 levels below me

reviewText:
A beautifully-crafted example of how to ruin a promising game with F2P baggage.

[review rewritten to explain more features instead of focusing solely on IAP complaints]

Here's the thing: MPQ is one of the (if not THE) best/most interesting match-3 games around. I've been a big fan of Puzzle Quest since the first game. The novelty of taking match-3 and building a battle system around it has never lost its appeal to me. MPQ takes that formula and makes it team-based, adding considerably more depth than the classic 1v1. If you happen to be interested in the Marvel universe, then there's some bonus appeal.

Puzzle Quest (and by extension MPQ) is different from the majority of the other match-3 games on the market. In a lot of other games, you're tasked with reaching point quotas or painting" every tile of the board with a match
date: etc. before you lock the board or run out of pre-budgeted moves or something. In Puzzle Quest
recommended: your goal is to deplete your enemies' health points
hoursPlayed: in classic turn-based RPG fashion.\n\nIn MPQ
voteText: you build up a roster of Marvel heroes (and villains) and pick a team of 3 to take into each battle. This edition has 6 mana colors
helpfulPercent: and each character has 3 preferred colors and up to 3 special abilities to spend your mana on. There are about a hundred characters available as of this writing
votesHelpful: so there are lots of combinations available. In addition to building a team with good color distribution
votesTotal: you must also weigh the characters' max health and what types of powers they have (raw damage
votesFunny: board effects
commentsCount: support abilities).\n\nUnfortunately
column16: the microeconomy severely limits your roster. Characters are unlocked via comic book Covers. Receiving your first Cover for a given character will make that character playable (if you have room to keep them)
column17: but in an extrememly weak and limited capacity. In order to get the most out of a character
column18: you have to collect at least 13 separate instances of that characer's Covers. The majority of your character Covers are acquired through blind-box pulls. You can also spend rare currency (about $3-4 worth per attempt) for a blind pull from any category that doesn't include any of the weakest characters. Even if you're willing to spend the money
column19:
there's absolutely no way to directly buy a character that you want. The best you can do is to buy microcurrency and keep spending it on blind boxes.

A character's strength & utility are determined by two factors: experience level & stacks of Covers. Rarer characters have higher starting levels and higher level caps. You can increase a character's level by spending the common currency (ISO crystals). It makes no difference how much you use the character. It's technically possible to completely max out a character without ever using them in a mission.

A new character can't level up without acquiring more Covers. Covers are the only way to raise the level cap. Not only that
column20: but you have to find 3 different version of a Cover to get access to all of the character's powers.\n\nI'll use classic Storm as an example
column21: because she's useful and popular and she has uncomplicated powers.\n(When you make a match
column22:
every tile you break goes into your mana pool so that you can spend it to cast your powers)
Storm's Green power breaks a bunch of random tiles around the board. Each tile deals damage & gives you mana.
Her Blue power will stun the target enemy for a set number of turns and also deal damage to the entire enemy team.
Her Yellow power doesn't cost anything
column23: but is an automatic counterattack whenever somebody on your team takes a certain amount of damage.\nSay you just got your first Storm Cover
column24: and it's Green. Now you can add Storm to your team
column25: but you can ONLY use her Green power. You won't be able to use her Blue or Yellow powers until you happen to receive those Covers. If you get ANOTHER Green Cover
column26: you can stack it. This increases the effectiveness of the power (in this case
column27: she breaks even more random tiles when you cast it
column28: resulting in higher damage and more mana gained) and also increases that character's level cap. Each color can be stacked to a total of five
column29: and you have to have 13 total applied to bring a character to maximum level.\n\nBecause of how Covers & levels are so closely intertwined
column30: you reach a point where newly-acquired characters are straight-up useless. If a lot of your roster is around
column33: and you get a new "Rare" character who begins at level 40
column34: you'll need to accumulate at least 5 or 6 extra covers (and spend currency to level up) before that character is strong enough (both in base stats and effectiveness of powers) to contribute to the fight. This is a real shame
column35: because it takes away the possibility of experimenting with combinations and turns it into a meta-game of trying to decide who to pour your resources into until they're viable.\n\nThe game's difficulty scales up based on the highest-level characters in your roster
column36: so if you luck out and win somebody much stronger than your existing team
column37: you will be punished for it with a difficulty increase even though that high-level character you just won is basically useless (due to not having any useable powers). You may end up having to sell the powerful new character just to make the game playable again.\n\nYou begin the game with enough space to keep 4 characters. You'll need to spend rare currency to unlock additional slots
column38: and the price goes up with every new slot. The price eventually caps out at roughly $10 per slot. It is possible to get rare currency without spending money.\n\nUnlike previous Puzzle Quest games
column39: your team isn't healed after a battle. Damage heals over time
column40: or it can be healed instantly using consumable Health Pack items. Health Packs can be bought (1 for 50 cents worth
column41: or 5 for $2). They can also be handed out as mission rewards. In the original release
column42: several characters were able to partially heal the entire team. These abilities were reworked so that this health  would wear off after the battle and you would still have to either wait or pay to heal back up. Characters like Wolverine who have self-only healing abilities get to keep their health after a fight.\n\nThe "Versus" mode is not live head-to-head PVP. Instead
column43: the game copies a ghost of your team and you battle AI-controlled versions of other players' ghost-teams. You gain points every time you defeat an enemy team
column44: but you lose some points every time your own ghost team is defeated. This is a pretty reasonable premise
column45: except that point losses don't just affect your leaderboard standing
column46: but also your ability to earn milestone rewards. It's incredibly frustrating to be one battle away from earning some rare currency or a weighted recruitment token
column47: only to find out after winning that you've been attacked by twelve other people during your battle and you've lost ten times the points that you just earned. The rub here is that you can spend rare currency (starting at 75 cents) to buy temporary immunity to point loss.\n\nIf this game wasn't built around a pay-for-a-chance-to-win microeconomy
column48: I would recommend it. Because so many decisions revolve around the microeconomy
column49: the game suffers and the players suffer. It's very easy to complain about the pay models in F2P games
column50: but the exchange rates are particularly disgusting here. It's easy to say "well
column51: if you normally pay $20-30 for a decent game
column52: then just buy $20-30 worth of currency and call it fair" except that much currency won't go very far.\n\nI love the Puzzle Quest series
column53: and I wish that I could play this game without constantly feeling somebody's hand grasping for my wallet. If there was a version of this game that wasn't built around IAP & only required a one-time purchase
column54: I would absolutely buy it. For now
column55: they'll have to be content with not getting my money
column56: and I hope they don't get yours either."

reviewText:
It's simply amazing how the good old bejeweld game can be converted into a 'story based' game with a huge cash grab.

Lets start with the 'story based' theme... Your own a team of Marvel heroes that need to grow in their powers. This is all done around a pretty thin story with extremely boring dialogues. Even before I was through the tutorial I kinda clicked all the dialogues away that boring are they!

And that brings me to the cash grab... To level your heroes you need Iso-8 AND LOTS OF IT! I was 'lucky' to recieve a legendary level 70 hero early in the game - he really made things extremely easy for me. Leveling up my other heroes I stumbled into the upcoming payment wall (cash grab). To level from level 20 to the next stage (it hops with quite a number of levels - around 4 or 5 at this point) I need over 3K Iso-8. That's either playing a lot (you get an average of 50 Iso-8 a game) or play with your creditcard and buy the 3K Iso-8 for around $5. And that's only at level 20. Remember that 'lukcy' drop I had of my level 70 hero..? I don't even want to know how many Iso-8 I need for that one!

Will I play this game for hours a day to grind for the Iso-8 I need to keep playing it..? No thanks! There are a lot better Free2Play games out there that offer a bigger variety in gameplay and are more fun. Not to mention, I do have more to do on a day than play Marvel Puzzle Quest for hours...

reviewText:
Marvel Puzzle Quest easily recommended to anyone who enjoys the match 3 genre or simply wants a good 'zen' game.  The gameplay mechanics are fantastic and the game itself has taken HUGE strides to become more and more free to play friendly over time.

Anyone who gets invested in this game might be surprised to learn that it has a healthy and welcome community attached to it through the forums and primarily through the LINE app.  This interaction with other players turns MPQ into more than just a game I pick up and play on occasion.

As an extremely hardcore player of Marvel Puzzle Quest I can easily see a lot of the games flaws as they pertain to character balance issues, reliance on lucky cover draws, the feeling that your roster improves and yet you continually face more challenging content rather that 'get ahead', becoming overwhelmed by characters but not enough room to keep them all, and the fact that competitive play demands far too much time from the player.

Those negatives aside the game at it's core is still fantastic to play and well worth recommending.
A solid 8/10 experience that can easily hook you if you let it.

reviewText:
I'm changing my review rating.

I had this review as as a recommend with reluctance but at this point it's a no.

The game has gone from sometimes unbalanced against the AI to extremely.  Doing away with the terrain tiles has just let the computer have an easier time beating me.

And this isn't me being bad at the game.

Blatant bugs that let the AI use moves they shouldn't, magical cascades that take out my entire party from full and just the fact that if you chose to use boosts you have no access to terrain powers.  That was one thing about the terrain I had liked, it was the same for both groups.

I'm limited by the space I have to try and decide if I want to power my characters or hope I can get enough TU tiles to use one of the boosts I've gotten.

I love the Marvel universe because of the movies and I will continue to play because of the time I've put into it, but if you've never played.

Don't waste or time or money.

reviewText:
I would love to recommend this game, but at it's current state it's a mixed bag. The puzzle element is really solid and damn addictive, I will go more in to the flaws at the end of the review,but if you want to enjoy it(without spending money) there are some tips.
1. Use most of the iso you get for training your heroes instead of buying covers, at least in the beginning, it is slow to grind with low level heroes on missions that you have already gathered all the iso from. Also focus on three heroes at the start, so you have at least one team that can defeat more difficult opponents.
2. Use the hero points for roster upgrades, the game limits how many heroes you can have and you very quickly fill all your slots.
3. You can't really reset your progress, so a bad start can really destroy enjoyment.
4. Start slow, you get some reward daily and they help you progress
5. Take part in events, they are really difficult at the very beginning and often require heroes you might not have. but they offer nice rewards and are generally entertaining. More so when you've played the game for a little longer.

What I hate about the game.
1.
Monetization, while not bad as a concept, this game has ridiculous prizes for it's currency, and as usual the more valuable resource is very limited ingame without paying. Events feature heroes that are powered up in them, and if you want to buy them quaranteed, it costs about 20 euros, hero slots start at about 1€ a spot but quickly double that. You get heroes at random, and if you want a copy of specific cover to level up power and also the level cap of the hero, you can spend money for that, 1 star hero is about 1€ per cover, 2 star is about 5€, 3 star cover is closer to 10€ and 4-star cover is about 25€.

You also can't buy new select covers for heroes, the powers have to be unlocked via randomly acquired cover or event prize. And after the power is unlocked the power could be upgraded by paying.

2.
Difficulty on campaign ramps up pretty fast, creating a paywall of some level that feels that appears very early, more so if you had a bad start.

3.
Campaign length. You start with a tab Prologue, that has 5 maps, each with about 15 battles. the difficulty really ramps up at the 4th one. Then when you finally clear the prologue, the campaign at least so far is over. After that there are only the events and pvp against other player teams that are controlled by AI. so the game becames more of a gotta catch them all, with no other real goal and that is handicapped by monetization.

4.Leveling
The whole leveling up system seems to have been designed with monetization in mind. You need iso to level up, the cost get higher and the rate at which you get it becomes slower when there are no new missions to play and old missions give almost negligible amounts. You hero's maximum level is capped by how many covers for him/her you have, and how rare the hero is

Some random numbers
Graphics 7. They are nice, not groundbreaking, but feel very fitting for this game
Gameplay 9. Very addicting once you get the hang of it, AI is kind of stupid at times which i guess just happens
Writing and sounds are decent but i mainly play on the background while doing something else so can't really rate them.
Monetization 2. everything feels like it has very bad value and not much incentive to use the option. And it really hurts the game
Overall 4. The actual gameplay is great, but is dragged down by lack of content, goals after the short campaign and monetization centric design.

reviewText: Honestly I've played the iOS version of the game, downloaded the PC version just to see whats it's like and I've gotta say... it's the same game. I'm not saying that it's a bad thing. I played the mobile version of the game for the last 2 months and I would recommend you to give it a try as it is a simple game to just turn on and play once in a while. My only gripe with the game is that there is no cloud syncing with the mobile version (even when cross platform play is available) as my roster of heroes are not available in the PC version.\n\nPS: Please bear in mind that this game is a mobile game in all aspects (from the countdown timer to the healing time). What I would recommend when playing on PC is that you pretend you're playing on a big tablet (if you don't like the idea of mobile games being ported to PC)

reviewText: A casual puzzle game with all kind of heroes from the Marvel universe. Takes a while to become a high(er) level player but with time and skill it's possible. In Marvel Puzzle Quest you get new heroes by spending recruit tokens. These tokens get you a random hero and the anticipation always excites me. The joy of getting a rare drop never gets old. Besides the game is free so if you don't like it, you can just drop it and nothing's lost.

reviewText:
I am a big fan of Marvel heroes, however this game is very tedious and monotonous. It is free to play, so the game steers you toward spending money in order to compete without spending hours on end grinding through the game, This game, overall, is bad.

This is a puzzle quest game.  You start off with a few 1 star characters and either earn others by playing the game or buying a chance to get certain characters. Characters range from 1 to 4 stars. Simply match gems to attack, no skill involved. Matchs drag on and useless animations, that you cannot disable, draws out these matches needlessly.

MPQ can get frustrating, and is very repetitive. When it is time for you to lose;  you will lose. The computer will cascade massive amounts of gem matches, continue to find extra turns, and color starve you until you lose. This happens often, how else would they get you to spend money to buy heals, a chance for characters, and levels.  I play on and off, but I would not recommend this game at all.

reviewText: I picked this up on a lark because of how much I enjoy match-3 type games (mindless, easy to play while watching T.V., etc).  Surprisingly, I've found this game to be really fun.  It's similar to Puzzle Quest in that there is added depth to the match-3 concept, and the PvP aspect as well as repeated Events keep me coming back.\n\nI'm editing this, as I see a ton of negative reviews due to the micro-transaction concept this game introduces.  It's a F2P game, the company has to make money so I don't see a problem with them charging to play more.  I've sank about $15 into this game and played for 30 hours, which is cheaper than most other forms of entertainment and quite a bit more I've gotten out of other games for similar price.  That being said, you don't need to pay a lot of cash.  Play smart, pick your fights, and you can pace yourself and naturally heal over time if that's your thing.

reviewText: I really love the concept of the game, but the unnecessary cool-downs on damaged heroes makes it feel more like a smartphone game then a PC game.  That sort of thing works fine for smart phones because the nature of the games are to be quick plays; but on a PC you want to sit down and get some serious playtime in a game. reviewText: It's a trap! All and all don't waste your money and time on this game, it's just too random.  Play for free or only use money to unlock roster slots.   Never ever pay to upgrade one star characters.\n\nThe monetization of this game is frustrating.  Unlocking characters and powers are one and the same and come from a random event called recruiting.  You roll the dice to get a character power, if you don't already have that character, they are added to your roster. So even when you are lucky enough to grab a rare three star character  they are useless until  you unlock their other powers which is extremely improbable.   Also unlocking levels of abilities is over priced.  Unlocking a single ability level on a three star character can cost (1250 points) ~$10 per level.  To compete in multiplayer challenges you need rare characters who can exceed level 50.  With that said, I'm hooked, hundreds of hours.... I can't get out.

reviewText: Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign has been out on iOS and Android for a few months now, and recently came out on Steam. While being free-to-play makes it harmless enough to check out, it is not one of the better games of this model out there. Tribes Ascend and Path of Exile are just a few examples of how this model can be applied to a game with great success. Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign gets 2 out of 5 stars. While most will get some passing enjoyment out of this puzzle game’s use of strategy and RPG elements, the sluggish UI and sub-par graphics, as well as the deluge of micro transactions, makes this one hard to recommend to even the most ardent of Marvel or Puzzle Quest fans.\n\nFull review at: http://www.hbhud.com/2013/12/09/review-of-marvel-puzzle-quest-dark-reign/
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Meh.

Oh, you wanted more?

Okay, mediocre swap-the-gems-to-get-three-or-more-in-a-row game. A few interesting rpg elements, character unlocks and upgrades, but nothing mind blowing or even new for that matter. If you've played Bejeweled you are an expert right from the start. You get to play a 'team' of heros, who each grant different attack values against the opposing team as you complete the puzzle. In addition each hero also have special direct attacks and gameboard effects that do add a second level of stratagy. Once you have defeated the oppsing team with your superior gem swapping, you win, granting various prizes such as more in game money, 'iso-8', or new hero unlocks.

GUI is poor with very little help tags or assistance. It looks polished, but a few pop-up tags would have been nice. The interface is confusing with clickable points not clearly identifiable.... making trying to navigate like playing a hidden picture flash game. Yes, this is a simple gem game... and a gamer of 25 yrs had trouble navigating the interface. I'm not proud of it... but there it is :P

As others point out, micro transactions are here, but truthfully not as prevelent as others make it seem. It is a fully playable free game, without limitaions.

That said... thats the only thing thats fitting and proper in this download - the price. If this game cost any more to play it would be too much.

reviewText:
So, today, after 200hours of playing I've lost my whole roster. Which means - Punisher, Hulk, Magnetos, Captain America, Spiderman, Ragnarok and many more(some of them maxed or half trained). As you can see on screens on my steam I was top player, have also played for more than 60 days in a row(know from daily shield rewards - which are bunch of crap tbh).

When I have played this game 3 months ago - it was fun on a break. Since then they've changed so many things on minus. It's free to play, but more pay(and play for whole day) to win. Tough enemies, weak player heroes making this game a real challenge, especially on a combo streak from enemy. I was maxing 2 stars Storm for last week - every fckin level needs about 1000 or later 1500 Iso-8, until 85 lvl. But still, after maxing you have to play against enemies - 140lvl, 240lvl - no problem with that, if you're lucky and know how to build your team for a battle. For beginners this game is now unplayable, because of level of the challenge. One of most unbalanced games I ever played.

Also develepers still pushing you to pay. You have lost a battle? You need recharge( so wait hours or pay). You want to level up? you need Iso-8. You want to win anything? Just pay!
You can say you get Iso from battles - yes, but how much? 100Iso as a reward of won match against deadly 240lvl enemies is piece of crap, not a reward.

Also, even if you buy gold, you want to have THIS character.. no no no! That's not that easy. Still you can't buy character you want, just test your luck. You probably get a character you have maxed, and it's useless until then.


TL:Dr - don't play, it's crap, pay to (maybe)win.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Whenever i see someone call this a game i can't help but laugh for at least a minute because in reality it is just a shameless attempt of a money making scheme, with the most serious offence being the health logic.

It has a health carry over after each fight, alongside a health pack limit of 5 and generating 1 every half hour (unless you have no value of money and can pay for more.) Meaning you have to stop playing after a few battles. Seriously, who in their right mind thought that limiting play time would be a good thing!

Trying to level up the powers of rarer characters is pretty much out of the question if you're avoiding spending money on them, which is ridiculous...

The story plummets after the first chapter (not that it was particularly interesting to begin with) and becomes a series of pointless fights with goons and soldiers.

Downloading this game as a Puzzle Quest installment or a Marvel game will only lead to disappointment. And do not mistake this as a free to play as you will find this game increasingly impossible the further you go.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It was a good game. On the beginning, if you are a new player, it's still good.

Pro:
- You have a good and enjoyable campaign
- You have some pvp events playable on low levels

Cont:
- The PVE events are terrible. 1-2 months ago they were good, but now they are totally unbalanced, if you dont have strong heroes, you will eb unable to start these events + you will need a lot of heals and ressurection - pay for play.
- The PVP events on higher lvl are about strong heroes - pay for win
- There isnt a new campaign, idk why, this part of the game is totally abandoned /it was for free, so the developers just dont care about it/
- a lot of bugs

Super cons, negatives, srsly, and thats smth new:

reviewText: This game is the utter definition of pay 2 win. With cash roadblocks at new characters, new skills, skill level ups, and healing, expect to find yourself grinding the same missions over and over hoping to make enough funny money to have a chance at earning a character that is strong enough to beat the next stage and having to wait up to a hour(at least for 30 and under) real time for your characters to heal back to full health. Since you can't level up without having more skill levels, and leveling up lower level characters is pointless anyways since their skills do not scale with the levels of HP, you're forced into this loop until you get a lvl 30 character that breaks the game for a few hours, until they are too weak as well.  Stick with the first 3 games, because this is game is a great example of what the F2P greedy cashgrab can do to a series.

reviewText:
I really enjoy this Match-3 game, between PC and Tablet I've put in well over 100 hours into it. Got every single reward from the tutorials, placed well in a few Story events (which are an interesting system of different timed thematical storyline events that spit out rewards every day or three) because I have pockets of time through the day which this fills nicely. Even dabbled a bit into the Versus system, where you fight other players' teams for rank and rewards, but the AI controls the opponent teams since Match-3 gameplay doesn't lend itself well to a realtime PvP system at all.

My roster's not as developed as long-time players yet, I have a bunch of 2-star heroes, a number of 3-stars with 1 or 2 powers, and a couple 4-stars from event rewards that I lean heavily on. (Star basically = rarity/power rating, with 1 stars being the lowest and 4 being the highest with a 5 now just released in an update). Enemies in story fights seems to scale according to your overall roster level, which is neat, because it allowed even my newer PC account to jump right in to a story event and place high enough to get top tier rewards.

The game is F2P with microtransactions, but the MT's are so RNG based that you don't really get to P2W very effectively unless you spend a ton, I think, and even then you can win loads of the same MT items just from several hours put into the story events, or by focusing your free time into an event that you think you can do well in.

Yet I hesitate to give this game a positive recommendation. I like it, but one thing really irks me. As a microtransaction-based game, it's unforgivable in my eyes that the accounts from different platforms play together but people cannot access their mobile account on PC and vice versa. If you are making a microtransaction game, especially since I noticed the mobile version already has Google+ and Facebook integration, you have to have this basic functionality since the game's pricing model is based on constantly spending money.

So while I like the game, I will not give it my recommendation until this is implemented as I feel that this is a necessary step for them to earn my thumbs up. They apparently have manually merged some accounts in the past" but have since stopped doing so for everyone else."

reviewText: Despite a lot of negative reviews criticizing this game for the microtransactions, I highly recommend it. The microtransactions are mainly for hero points
date: which is a rare currency in the game that is mainly used for increasing your roster size and letting you collect more heroes/villains. I have played for about 30 hours at the time of this review without a single penny spent and I've loved it. Now that we've covered the microtransactions, the real review.\nMarvel Puzzle Quest is a match three game, like Candy Crush Saga or Bejeweled. Each team has three heroes (or villains) per battle, and each match you make gives damage to the enemy team. You can earn more characters for your team by completing battles, winning PvP and campaign events, or buying them using Iso-8 (another currency which is much more common) and Hero Points. PvP Events are released frequently, which let you fight another player's team which is usually paired up with a hero from that event, like Deadpool or Wolverine. There's also a campaign mode where you fight game A.I. for Iso-8 and sometimes Hero Points.\nOverall, I'd say it's a really cool game and despite all the negative reviews, you should download it and check it out.

reviewText:
This is good attempt to make F2P from Puzzle Quest. There are only familiar PQ battles - no pets, no equip, no locks - only the battles. But they are quite good. And the upgrading Marvel heroes instead equip makes it interesting too. There is one problem though - the new heroes requires a new slots, and without slots you most probably will miss your special rewards. But game was quite generous to give me 7 slots from initial questing money, and later... well, I shell be able to manage it later. But if you want the many different heroes, fast, prepare to pay.

As it's F2P, payment or grinding for battle wins expected, as usual. All your heroes lose life force during the battles, and it can be gained only with time - or with the health packs->donations. So if you want a long games, prepare to pay. For me and my half-hour sessions it's all right.

The game have quite a big amount of NPC-grinding locations, but most challenges came from PvP battles in special events. Unfortunately, most of time (but not always) it means losing. For my non-buffed heroes one-two battles per day is manageable, but rarely more. But as rewards are much bigger than loses, nothing to complain for me. If I cannot kill today's enemies, I'll farm NPC instead.

Bottom line: good PQ-like game for 20-30 minutes per day. Can be frustrating for longer.

reviewText:
The gameplay is so much fun - a great time killer. The same old Bejeweled/PQ basic mechanic of 'matching 3 gems or more' is there, a huge appeal for its fanbase.

Also, with the quests system, there's a sense of progression unlike the old Bejeweled. You actually need to check your opponents level prior to accepting the quest, rearrange your roster, heal your heroes or arming the power ups to make things easier.

In addition to great quests, we also have very decent graphic and badass OSTs. Granted that it's not AAA's 3D levels, but the detailed chars and charming designs are more than enough. The actual Heads Up Display is clear and concise, allowing players to reach the menu they want to use. There's also a simple descriptions to each of heroes' powers so you can understand what you're going to invoke before deciding (since the point placement is permanent and not respecable).

The video options are barebones, but really there's no need Anti Aliasing and those fancy Physx Tesselation whatever it's called options. You can use your native resolutions - at least that's commonly used nowadays - to prevent screen tearing. Well, in my case, it autodetected everything so it's click and play.

Game performance overall is silky smooth even on my mid-end rig. Transitions between scenes are quite short, no boring loading screen that takes ages to finish and so far zero crash.

Now after all good stuffs, here comes the problem, microtransactions. In order to upgrade your heroes within reasonable timeframe, you need to either be lucky with rewards rolls, or grind the best rewarding quess repeatedly, or purchasing DLCs. That's where the major problem is. All would have been a little better if the quest rewards can make up for it so free players don't have to bang against the wall out of frustration.

Multiplayer is missing, but I'd imagine it'd be great to have a match up against other people real time matching gems together.

Great Free to Play game ridden by micro transactions. It's a real shame, the game has a chance to be other FTP killers on Steam, but severely missed it. In the end though, I'd play until I am tired with the brick wall that prevents me from advancing, or bored.

reviewText:
Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign

Marvel Puzzle Quest is the newest game in the Puzzle Quest line of games. This series has seen a lot of iterations and copycats over the years, with none being nearly as successful as the original title. This latest is an officially licensed Marvel title with the Puzzle Quest formula. It has the added benefit of being entirely free-to-play. You may of course purchase bonuses like any other free title, but these purchases are not required to play the full game. Is this latest attempt at a Puzzle Quest success worth a look, or should you just let it speed by and fade into the distance? Keep reading, perhaps I can help you decide.

To begin with, the Marvel universe has been utilized pretty well here. You have a team of three characters, each with three possible powers to be used. Typically you begin with one of these powers and you must find comic covers of the character to unlock or upgrade said powers. This also allows you to level up your character a little bit more each time. It’s a system that constantly keeps you feeling like you’re making some kind of progress and it works very well. Winning battles and missions grants you rewards, randomized from a pool of up to four for each story mission, giving you reasons to play missions again and again until you’ve received every reward available. It’s structured remarkably well for any game, let alone a free-to-play title. It’s a nice change of pace to see a free game with a lot of effort put into it. The content level is more than a lot of full priced games have, and the developers deserve some credit for it.

The presentation is decent. Each character is represented by a comic book cover from any number of different Marvel universes, and has a full 3D model as well as a 2D comic profile. Everything is vibrant and colorful and stands out very well in a sea of photo-realistic browns and grays of more recent games. The music is a bit generic, but it’s suitable for a superhero game. There are lots of highs and thumping bass tracks to drive the combat forward. It can certainly get repetitive, but that’s what the volume slider in the options menu is for. Overall, it doesn’t detract from the experience any and fits in well enough that some may not really notice it.

On to the meat of things; the gameplay! I’m pleased to say that the gameplay of Marvel Puzzle Quest is, well, fantastic to be perfectly honest with you. It is a very well implemented use of the Puzzle Quest formula with enough difference and excitement to stand well on its own feet. Each color is representative of one member of your team, and has an icon to indicate which member that is. Wolverine, for example, is represented by scratch marks across the gems, while Storm has lightning bolts. Each icon makes sense and stands out well, making it easy to determine who will be attacking. Collecting gems allows you to use character powers, which can drastically change the way a fight is going. More powerful abilities take more preparation time and cause severe damage, while less powerful abilities can be used more often but do less damage or have fewer utility effects attached. There is a story mode separated into four separate mission groups, which will last you a good number of hours to complete. There are also daily and weekly missions and a PVP mode to keep you playing as long as your interest remains. Each of these modes offers its own rewards and characters, and as a result each also adds a huge amount of content to the game.

As for the dreaded free-to-play purchased content that inevitably unbalances these games? Well…it is present, but it’s not nearly as bad as other games often are. You can purchase the two currencies present in the game in bulk quantities, and use those currencies to recruit more and rarer characters or power up your existing heroes. It does unbalance the multiplayer somewhat if you let it, but it’s not so bad that it ruins the game entirely in that department. In order to counter the unbalancing, you just have to search a bit harder for an opponent on the same level as you. It can definitely be a pain in the backside from time to time but it isn’t something that ruins the overall experience and shouldn’t keep you from giving the game a shot.

Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign has far more content and playability than a free game should ever reasonably be expected to contain. If you let it, this game will suck you in and keep you playing into the wee hours of the morning without even realizing it. There are far worse ways you could be spending your free time. Don’t let the price tag fool you; this is one game that doesn’t skimp on the content just because it’s free of charge. Give it a shot and you might be pleasantly surprised.

reviewText:
This game is Marvel vs. Capcom meets Bejeweled. Its a match 3 game with 3v3 combat. There are 6 colored jewels and environmental tiles. Match 3 of a color to acquire AP of said color. Your Heros use the AP for special abilities. The strategy in this game comes from setting up a team of 3 with synergistic abilities. You want to be able to utilize all 6 colors and you dont want one hero out too long or they will take too much damage.

DIfferent types of challenges require different strategies. Some PC villians use tiles with count down timers. You have to eliminate or delay those tiles with your abilities or take massive cascades of damage. Other times you have to acquire certain colors to keep them away from villians in a turn based game play. You can use AP as you acquire it or save it to combine multiple abilities in board clearing strategies that will allow you to play above your character level.

Overall this game has a depth that is surprising and exceeds its genre. Start free to play and then decide if its worth investing.

reviewText:
I think the reviews for this game thus far have been a little harsh.

Yes, there are ample microtransactions, and at times you do feel like there's nothing to do if you want to recruit that rare hero card you just got, because there's no other way to expand your stable without spending coins bought with real money.

However, its also not your average match 3 game.  The heroes have special attacks which use differing amounts of the gems you collect from matching them.  This means using more complicated gameplay than just matching tiles until one side emerges the victor.  Environment tiles add an additional layer of gameplay, but this game isn't the type you'll play all night, every night- and shouldn't be judged as such.

As a lover of marvel, I enjoy the variety of heroes they've incorporated so far and am looking forward to more.  I also think the artwork is nice, but do agree there is little feeling of story progression as you go from battle to battle.
All in all, I enjoy this game.  There are various improvements I could suggest, but instead I'll just log on from time to time, have a few fights and enjoy myself, level up my characters a bit with the currency I gain from my wins and then log back off and do something else.

If you take offence at microtransactions then don't click the page with them on, but if you're a grown up and understand that the option is there but is by no means a neccessity, then by all means, give the game a try- it's worth a look if you're a fan of Marvel and match 3 games.

reviewText:
Yes it's very much in beta, but you would be better off playing Marvel Heroes (especially if you've bought any of their DLC) rather than paying for it again in, what is, just Bejeweled with power-ups and a simple story attached.

That said, if you treat it as a game you spend a few minutes in? It will be an okay, but not great, experience.  I have to wonder how many children with a Steam account would play this though because, as I see it, anyone who is 15 years old and above would see through the transparent nature of the game and be against these kind of microtransactions from the get-go.  Then again, there are those who are playing Hearthstone and buying card packs for that...so no doubt there are some that will buy for this too.

In any event, right now I couldn't recommend this game.  Something to revisit in a few months perhaps, just to see if there have been any improvements.

reviewText: Marvel Puzzle Quest (MPQ), is a mobile device port for steam. Is that necessarily a bad thing? I don't think so, but it is something that you need to keep in mind when looking at the UI and graphics. It also effects the pay system, and since this is a F2P game, that's something people tend to focus on. So let's start there:\n\nCan you play MPQ without spending money? Yes. Will you be competitive... well, mostly. Let's talk about what real money gets used for: You can purchase the two types of in-game currency with real money. ISO and Gold. ISO is used, mainly, to purchase boosts for use during combat and to spend to level up your characters. It is the common currency of the game and is earned pretty easily. Gold can be used for a number of things. You can purchase additional slots to hold more characters (you are limited to 4 characters at the start and the prices for additional slots increases the more you have), you can purchase some super-boosts"
recommended: and you can purchase additional covers for your characters. Do you "have" to purchase these things? Nope. You do earn some gold through normal game play
hoursPlayed: and many people (myself included) have found that if you focuse your purchases you don't really hit a wall for a very long time.\n\nLet's move onto the gameplay itself. MPQ is a tile matching game that is themed around the Marvel Comic Universe. You swap tiles on a grid board to make 3 or longer chains of the same color/shape (think Bejewelled)
voteText: you then score a hit dealing damage and (in most cases) generated Ability Points (AP) of that color. Each character that you have selected (three) will have different abilities both passive and active. These abilities are often fuelled by the AP you generate from your matches. Pretty simple. There is an entertaining amount of depth in selecting which team you want to bring to an event
helpfulPercent: and finding good synergy between character abilities is important.\n\nThe characters are leveled up by unlocking their skills. Skills are found by getting random drop "Covers". Each cover has one skill associated with it. Once you have used that cover to train the character in that skill it will increase the "Current Max Level" of the character
votesHelpful: you can then use ISO to increase the level of the character. Every level increase raises the max Hit Points of the character
votesTotal: the amount of damage they do and the effectivness of their skills. Once you have unlocked the first level of the skill you can use Gold to increase the skill level (this is the main form of Pay-to-Win that you see in the game
votesFunny: but is limited by the fact that you have to have the base skill first to buy it).\n\nHealth of your characters is the delaying factor in playing. Not only are you doing damage to your enemies
commentsCount: but they are doing damage to your characters as well. Their health will increase back to max over time
column16: but with high level characters this can take several hours. If you take your three best characters into a match that is over their head and get them all killed
column17: this can mean that you don't get to play again for a few hours... unless you use Health Packs. Health packs allow a character to return to full health immediately. You earn health packs over time
column18: one every 30 minutes
column19: but could buy additionals for Gold.\n\nThe game provides some basic "PVE" missions to get a feel for the game and earn some basic covers and boosts
column20: but the main part of the game that allows you to progress is the "PVP" duels and "PVE" events. Events rotate every few days and give opportunities for rare and high end rewards
column21: but competition can be tough and some events require having certain characters to participate. Duels are a staple way to put your team against another player. The duels aren't really PVP though
column22: because the same AI that runs the normal missions just uses the team
column23: not an actual player.\n\nLong and the short of it: I find MPQ to be very entertaining
column24: something that I have spent many an hour with and am perfectly happy to keep playing. There are issues
column25: some bugs that break events and some exploits that people have found that can let them rank up super fast
column26: and there are concerns about Pay-To-Win
column27: but overall I can say that if you are looking for a casual time waster
column28: this does the job rather well."

reviewText:
I love the Puzzle Quest games. So naturally I also loved this new entry based on the Marvel comics. And in a way I do. But it just feels so cheap, and all because it's free. The character designs are well done and if you've played one of the previous PQ games you most definitely know how they play and this one is no different. It's once again all about matching gems. Which is fun obviously.

But unlocking new characters, powers and upgrades take a lot of time and you'll be replaying a lot of battles to earn these rewards... or you can use real life currency to save time, which is ridiculous if you ask me. I'm aware of the fact that I own a lot of games and they've cost me tons of money but one thing I will rarely do (never say never) is pay for in-game content. And yes, DLC is a whole different story. But less of a scam because some of it can be truly impressive. But I'm losing focus here.

The text in the text bubbles is gigantic which annoyed me. Replaying the levels many times over to get the proper rewards annoyed me. The fact that you can skip through these steps as long as you are willing to spend money on it annoyed me. And it's such a shame, because it can really be a fun game once you're playing a battle.

It's free so it's hard to not recommend this game, right ? But I just can't. I can't. Buy PQ2 instead and witness a truly magnificent game. You won't be disappointed.

[Rating: 76/100]

reviewText:
Marvel Puzzle Quest is, at the core, a pretty fun experience. There are quite a few characters to aquire for your team (a number which continues to grow as the developers add more characters to the game) and they generally come with unique play mechanics that make certain combinations more effective than others.

Characters aside, however, this game falls off the bus very quickly. The game is inaccurately marketed as free to play when, in fact, the only players who will realisitcally be competitive in tournaments or see the end of the single player campaign are the ones who have shelled out anywhere between 50-100 dollars. If you hope to max out your heroes and keep up with the ever growing roster be prepared to spend even more money (100 dollars is not nearly enough to max out a decent character's level).

Unfortunately this is not a game I would ever recommend to any sane person. The costs are just too high and the returns too low. When, if ever, the pay to win mechanic is removed this could easily be one of the better puzzle rpgs. Until then stay far away. Marvel Puzzle Quest is a huge disappointment.

reviewText:
This is a frustrating game because there are so many parts of it that could be so good. But that was months ago for me and the longer I play and the longer I see what the devs are doing to the game the less I even enjoy the parts of it that I once did.  Nearly every change since I started playing has been for the worse.

It lulls you into thinking that it might be easy or playable when you first start because the matchmaking and enemy difficulty seems to understand how to scale with you at that point but the longer you play the more all of that goes out the window. It becomes this banal uphill struggle for any foothold to just get a measly amount of ISO to level up. And that doesn't matter anyway, the better you do the harder they make they game so you'll do worse the next week until it evens out to just doing boringly.

I did spend money on this game, not a lot but that's not the point. This isn't a pay to win game, I mean it could be but only if you put in hundreds of dollars but before an input of that size you're really not getting that much, if anything, out of putting money into this game, Maybe I'm wrong and all the people that seem to win every tournament or even any PvE event are putting money into the game but I don't think so, I just think they started earlier when there was less competition.

That's all this game is, an endless and fruitless competition. I've gotten close to even winning a few tournaments but it was a really hollow thing to do that. You have to throw all your time and effort to come away with anything at all and if you play casually you'll get next to nothing because there is nothing outside of the prologue that isn't played against other people and unless you can throw hours and hours and hours a day into this game then past the prologue you'll just founder and flail.

It might seem appealing now but don't bother. It will suck the marrow from your bones and leave you wishing you never started. Just go play some old Puzzle Quest games and look up some Marvel Trading cards online to look at, it won't be as enticing but at least it won't leave as bitter as I am at this mess of a game.

reviewText:
Free to play, pay to win taken to the next level.

-Pay money if you lose in a stage or wait until your characters recover, recovery time varies from minutes to HOURS!
-To level up your characters and progress you need to pay money or be lucky with random drops
-Unlocking hero skills can cost 110 Euros or take a lot of luck

I was browsing through the f2p games for a bit and wanted a simple game to kill some time since i didn´t really felt like playing one of my games or wasting some time on the internet. That´s how i stumbled upon this seemingly innocent little puzzle game. I always liked superheroes and so i decided to give it a shot. But what was in store for me was actually just a really mean ways of grabbing money. Don´t get me wrong im more than willing to spend a few bucks on a f2p game if i get the feeling it´s a fun game and some real effort went into it. That´s also the reason i own some skins in League of Legends for example.
But this here is just a tired puzzle game programmed to bring frustration. It´s hard to explain without having played it, but imagined that you feel cheated in many of the stages. Since there is no time limit you can and have to plan your moves and the basic concept of lining up 3 pieces of the same color can be expanded by planning where the remaining pieces will drop once you remove 3 of them. In some of the stages you are the only one directly moving pieces while the computer just adds pieces with certain effects that harm you, while in others the computer tries to remove pieces aswell. Now i put some planning into my moves trying to maximize the outcome and even chaining pieces and so on, but no matter what sometimes the computer just decides to drop the right pieces for your opponent deliberately. I know this might sound a little like a sore loser, but imagine you spend a few minutes thinking and you make a move that removes a lot of pieces via chains and then the computer just drops 5 pieces of the same color in his turn, dealing even more damage than you did.
Ok, ok you might say this is where the difficulty comes from, but it´s just my subjective point of view that it feels incredibly cheap. Also this isn´t the real problem of the game, remember i said somthing about greed and pay to win. When you loose in a stage your heroes faint and will need time to recover after the battle. How long you might ask? How about 2 FU***** hours? Go do your laundry, plant a tree or beat up a hobo, because you will wait or pay. As you level up your heroes they gain more hitpoints but also if they die/faint in a battle it takes forever until you can use them again, unless you pay money... Wow this is farmville standard bulls*** and pretty much what totally kills the game for me.
Of course you can own more heroes in case your team gets defeated but the number of heroes you can own/use is limited, how can you own more heroes? Find ingame currency after certain bossbattles or pay money. This ain´t so bad right? After i acquire a hero i´m all set, right? Nope. All the heroes need to level up before they are actually useful in a stage, they all start with low hitpoints and just 1 skill. Furthermore they have a maxlevel capacity of 6 out of let´s say 85, which means you can´t progress until you unlock their higher levels. They can gain maxlevels and skills by finding comicbookcovers after stages, or by buying them. More rare heroes are more powerful and more expensive and can be leveled up beyond the level of your weak starting heroes. Now lets calculate how much 1 hero costs. Assuming you are lucky and get a 3 star hero after buying a random cover for 2 Euros, let´s say Loki for example. Each of his 9 remaing skill points comes at a whooping 12 Euros, which means you would in theory spend 110 Euros on one playable character... wow just wow. For 110 Euros you can buy the lengendary edition of Skyrim... 3 times. Also don´t forget your stronger heroes still need to gain levels until they reach their unlocked maxlevel via Iso-8 but i spare you from calculating that aswell.
I have no idea how IGN.com and the other fu**-ups that call themselves reviewers can find this scam of a game even playable, but i assume they haven´t even played it and just wrote whatever the developing company paid them to do.
In my opionion you should stay as far away from this piece of sh** as possible.

reviewText:
~100 hours for this game. Recent patches made it a disaster. When earlier it could be both casual and competitive at the same time, now its gone worse than pay2win, it made a severe turn for pay2play. In tournaments the rich get richer and new players get f***** up real good. Earlier the developers were co-operative with the community and the game was fun and even a newcomer could make a significant impact on the tournament standings and get some awesome rewards.

Don't you worry! the game has microtransactions and you will NEED to spend money on this monstrosity in order to progress or get any rankings in the tournaments.

Balancing has gone a rough way, the first big changes to characters came up from nowhere dimilishing their potential entirely. Once a overused always seen char went to plain common or even bad, changes just were too radical and unexpected. The most balancing issue was doubling the common booster prices and making the best boosts costing in-game currency which is nearly impossible to get without spending real money, so... want to fight with the best ways? Okay, go ahead and pay 50cents for each fight, doesnt sound bad? Yeah for the most part you will need at least 40 matches in a tournament to get to the good positions, thats like 20 bucks for simply trying to play the game! Character's skills can also be boosted! only 3-20$ for each cover which you need 15 in order to make one of your characters most useful, not mentioning the huge money drop (a ridicilous amount needed) for boosting it's levels.

TL;DR Once a fun and an exciting game 5/5 went to greedy as ♥♥♥♥ microtransactions simply for playing the game, dont even consider supporting the developers. As a free to play -player you cant get anything done.

reviewText:
This is a frustrating game because there are so many parts of it that could be so good. But that was months ago for me and the longer I play and the longer I see what the devs are doing to the game the less I even enjoy the parts of it that I once did.  Nearly every change since I started playing has been for the worse.

It lulls you into thinking that it might be easy or playable when you first start because the matchmaking and enemy difficulty seems to understand how to scale with you at that point but the longer you play the more all of that goes out the window. It becomes this banal uphill struggle for any foothold to just get a measly amount of ISO to level up. And that doesn't matter anyway, the better you do the harder they make they game so you'll do worse the next week until it evens out to just doing boringly.

I did spend money on this game, not a lot but that's not the point. This isn't a pay to win game, I mean it could be but only if you put in hundreds of dollars but before an input of that size you're really not getting that much, if anything, out of putting money into this game, Maybe I'm wrong and all the people that seem to win every tournament or even any PvE event are putting money into the game but I don't think so, I just think they started earlier when there was less competition.

That's all this game is, an endless and fruitless competition. I've gotten close to even winning a few tournaments but it was a really hollow thing to do that. You have to throw all your time and effort to come away with anything at all and if you play casually you'll get next to nothing because there is nothing outside of the prologue that isn't played against other people and unless you can throw hours and hours and hours a day into this game then past the prologue you'll just founder and flail.

It might seem appealing now but don't bother. It will suck the marrow from your bones and leave you wishing you never started. Just go play some old Puzzle Quest games and look up some Marvel Trading cards online to look at, it won't be as enticing but at least it won't leave as bitter as I am at this mess of a game.

reviewText:
Free to play, pay to win taken to the next level.

-Pay money if you lose in a stage or wait until your characters recover, recovery time varies from minutes to HOURS!
-To level up your characters and progress you need to pay money or be lucky with random drops
-Unlocking hero skills can cost 110 Euros or take a lot of luck

I was browsing through the f2p games for a bit and wanted a simple game to kill some time since i didn´t really felt like playing one of my games or wasting some time on the internet. That´s how i stumbled upon this seemingly innocent little puzzle game. I always liked superheroes and so i decided to give it a shot. But what was in store for me was actually just a really mean ways of grabbing money. Don´t get me wrong im more than willing to spend a few bucks on a f2p game if i get the feeling it´s a fun game and some real effort went into it. That´s also the reason i own some skins in League of Legends for example.
But this here is just a tired puzzle game programmed to bring frustration. It´s hard to explain without having played it, but imagined that you feel cheated in many of the stages. Since there is no time limit you can and have to plan your moves and the basic concept of lining up 3 pieces of the same color can be expanded by planning where the remaining pieces will drop once you remove 3 of them. In some of the stages you are the only one directly moving pieces while the computer just adds pieces with certain effects that harm you, while in others the computer tries to remove pieces aswell. Now i put some planning into my moves trying to maximize the outcome and even chaining pieces and so on, but no matter what sometimes the computer just decides to drop the right pieces for your opponent deliberately. I know this might sound a little like a sore loser, but imagine you spend a few minutes thinking and you make a move that removes a lot of pieces via chains and then the computer just drops 5 pieces of the same color in his turn, dealing even more damage than you did.
Ok, ok you might say this is where the difficulty comes from, but it´s just my subjective point of view that it feels incredibly cheap. Also this isn´t the real problem of the game, remember i said somthing about greed and pay to win. When you loose in a stage your heroes faint and will need time to recover after the battle. How long you might ask? How about 2 FU***** hours? Go do your laundry, plant a tree or beat up a hobo, because you will wait or pay. As you level up your heroes they gain more hitpoints but also if they die/faint in a battle it takes forever until you can use them again, unless you pay money... Wow this is farmville standard bulls*** and pretty much what totally kills the game for me.
Of course you can own more heroes in case your team gets defeated but the number of heroes you can own/use is limited, how can you own more heroes? Find ingame currency after certain bossbattles or pay money. This ain´t so bad right? After i acquire a hero i´m all set, right? Nope. All the heroes need to level up before they are actually useful in a stage, they all start with low hitpoints and just 1 skill. Furthermore they have a maxlevel capacity of 6 out of let´s say 85, which means you can´t progress until you unlock their higher levels. They can gain maxlevels and skills by finding comicbookcovers after stages, or by buying them. More rare heroes are more powerful and more expensive and can be leveled up beyond the level of your weak starting heroes. Now lets calculate how much 1 hero costs. Assuming you are lucky and get a 3 star hero after buying a random cover for 2 Euros, let´s say Loki for example. Each of his 9 remaing skill points comes at a whooping 12 Euros, which means you would in theory spend 110 Euros on one playable character... wow just wow. For 110 Euros you can buy the lengendary edition of Skyrim... 3 times. Also don´t forget your stronger heroes still need to gain levels until they reach their unlocked maxlevel via Iso-8 but i spare you from calculating that aswell.
I have no idea how IGN.com and the other fu**-ups that call themselves reviewers can find this scam of a game even playable, but i assume they haven´t even played it and just wrote whatever the developing company paid them to do.
In my opionion you should stay as far away from this piece of sh** as possible.

reviewText:
I love the Puzzle Quest games. So naturally I also loved this new entry based on the Marvel comics. And in a way I do. But it just feels so cheap, and all because it's free. The character designs are well done and if you've played one of the previous PQ games you most definitely know how they play and this one is no different. It's once again all about matching gems. Which is fun obviously.

But unlocking new characters, powers and upgrades take a lot of time and you'll be replaying a lot of battles to earn these rewards... or you can use real life currency to save time, which is ridiculous if you ask me. I'm aware of the fact that I own a lot of games and they've cost me tons of money but one thing I will rarely do (never say never) is pay for in-game content. And yes, DLC is a whole different story. But less of a scam because some of it can be truly impressive. But I'm losing focus here.

The text in the text bubbles is gigantic which annoyed me. Replaying the levels many times over to get the proper rewards annoyed me. The fact that you can skip through these steps as long as you are willing to spend money on it annoyed me. And it's such a shame, because it can really be a fun game once you're playing a battle.

It's free so it's hard to not recommend this game, right ? But I just can't. I can't. Buy PQ2 instead and witness a truly magnificent game. You won't be disappointed.

[Rating: 76/100]

reviewText:
A fairly interesting match-3 game, that uses collection of power from the colored tiles to activate special abilities that are stored in your characters.

Unfortunately, progress past a certain point requires you to 'upgrade' your characters with copies of eachother. In the early game this is easy because the characters are common, but very quickly you hit a ceiling and must pay. There is no community market, no way to trade your roster of superheroes with other peoples - they hold all the cards and want your money.

It's a shame - lots of potential. Hopefully they fix it. Until then, no more for me.

reviewText: On the surface, it looks like a fairly decent Puzzle Quest/Match 3 style game. But when you dig deeper you find that the game is designed to squeeze you for money every chance it gets. Your heroes' levels are capped by comic covers. The covers are mostly random, or hard to obtain. Plus, despite there being several different covers available, your slots to place them in are extremely limited. The Single-Player game will thus become overywhemling quickly, and stop providing you with any resources, forcing you into the special quests (which likewise dry up fast) or pvp. Those have exploitable methods to try to get more resources, but it becomes a frustrating game of retrying until you get a suitable opponent and then attacking. Not a lot of balance, difficult to advance, very hard on the wallet for a freemium" game

reviewText:
Marvel Puzzle Quest (in general, mobile and Steam) is nothing more than a petty rich get richer pyramid scheme. People who played from day one got to cruise to a cushy position for free and they are inoculated to the countless nerfs and adjustments that hurt new to mid range players in a petty attempt to force them to pay money for what others got for free just months before. Some fall into the trap and pay while others just tell everyone they know at how (supposedly) great the game is to flood the leaderboards with noobs so that they will be elevated into the top 10% more easily. Everything about the game is catered towards paying to overcome those who had it easier than you because they started at a higher tier in the pyramid scheme.

The steam version has several advantages over the mobile version, but with a single colossal flaw. By virtue of having more space the in game interface is vastly superior to the hyper-compact view on mobile. The perpetual link to the server forces the battery to drain 8-12X regular drain rate on mobile, which is not a problem on Steam given that we have that constant connection anyway and we are generally plugged in to a power source that will charge faster than it will drain. The problem is that Facebook cannot be synced, so you cannot carry over your mobile save data to your Steam version. This mortal sin is making me uninstall.

0 out of 100

reviewText:
As far as casual games go, this one is pretty epic in it's time-consuming...ness. I enjoy it quite a bit, but I've always been a fan of puzzle games, not excluding the 'match 3' genre. This one isn't as in-depth as say... Puzzle Quest 2 which is made by a totally different company, but I think there's still enough there if you want something more than Bejewelled. I think the best part is figuring out which heroes/villains work the best together and trying to build up their combos and such.

As far as downsides go, I really don't like the weak AI, the randomness of drops and the money for power aspect. I'll go into each point by point here.

The only real challenge comes from the level of your opponent, which determines how much HP they have and damage they do. When it comes to the actual gameplay, you can easily predict what they're going to do as they have certain priorities. They definitely play worse than a thinking person would. I would like it more if they made better decisions, as frustrating as that could be.

As far as getting loot goes, you have very little control over what you get. Essentially you do different missions, most of which have four rewards. The first time you beat a mission, you're guaranteed one of them. Typically, you'll get ISO (the game's main currency) Hero Coins (the game's premium currency), heroes or random hero tokens, or boosts. Each time you repeat the mission, you'll have a chance to get a reward that you haven't already received or 20 ISO (which is a tiny tiny amount) This does get frustrating after a while, especially if you're trying to get a specific reward. Now, in order to get more characters, you need to either complete certain missions, trade in recruit tokens of varying quality or progress/place well enough in events (there's usually something going on every day). The problem here is with the tokens. Some guarantee a certain quality of hero, but it's still random since if there's a character you want, there's next to no guarantee you'll get them. They break down the odds on their website, but it doesn't really help. But that's not the worst thing.

The worst thing is of course the bane of most free-to-play games. Paying for power. You can buy two things: ISO and Hero coins, the two currencies of the game. ISO is used to level up your characters and buy more low-quality ones. Coins allow you to buy more recruit tokens of higher quality, level up hero powers, (which aside from their actual effects, allow you to raise the character level higher) protect your characters in PvP mode (>:| ) but most importantly, buy more slots for characters. That last one is really frustrating, because you can only increase your character slots with coins, and if you don't want to spend money, you're going to have to inevitably pass up on recruiting certain characters, or get rid of ones you've progressed on in order to get new ones simply because if you don't buy coins, it's a hell of a grind to get more. The worst of the worst is that the coins/ISO are really expensive for your dollar, and I think don't really give you proper value. If you want to make this one of the only games you play it might be acceptable, but if you want to just play casually, I highly recommend not spending the money on it.

Myself, I've put in a fair amount of time, so I begrudgingly purchased some coins to help open up some space for more characters on both my steam account and my iPad. ~sigh~

Anyways, if you can overlook all the shortcomings, it's still a fun puzzle game, and you CAN get by without dropping any of your hard-earned cash on it. I recommend giving it a try if you're into the genre at all, especially considering it IS free.
