reviewText:
8/30/14 - Changed review to positive, though I imagine it still would be much more of a burden for people starting out to have to deal w/ massive downtimes when they don't have the roster to pick and choose, and remain competitive, when they run out of lives and have to wait, I still enjoy the game quite a bit.  I don't like the new healing mechanic that limits your healing to in-battle only regeneration, but, it's not as much of a game breaker as I had expected.  But again, that might be due to the depth of my roster and having multiple options to choose from in order to play-on while out of lives/regens.  Give it a whirl though, it is addictive.


As you can see I have been intensely addicted to this game for months now.  And the game WAS fantastic.  However, in what I still cannot comprehend, the dev's at D3 have decided that they no longer want people to become addicted to their game.  They no longer want us telling our friends how fun it is, how they should give it a go and become MPQ addicts like we are.  No... now they have taken any sense of allowing their players the freedom to play when they want, how they want, w/ whatever characters they CHOOSE to play and have thrown it all in the garbage.

I am an AVID supporter of games and developers who show that they care for, listen to, and support the player community which gives them a job, a fan base, and a slew of addicts who advertise this game as a wonderful time-sink to all their friends/family/co-workers for free.  But apparently, FREE advertising doesn't figure into their bottom line and they would rather lose 1000's of loyal players if it means that 1-2 people w/ the fortune and freedom to invest money at will into buying extra lives every time the RNG unluckily kills off all their characters.  Loyal players who will NEVER pay for, what would be, an endless need for health-packs to keep playing at the times these players have allotted themselves to play... are GONE.  The only competition new players, or even players looking to experiment and try different character/team set-ups, will face are going to be these whales that invest so much money into the game that they are UNBEATABLE.  NO NEW PLAYER WILL STAND A CHANCE when the only competition left are those with pockets deep enough to make it utterly unfair.

I will continue to log on 1x -2x a day, in hopes that the dev's will realize, acknowledge, and correct this unfathomably inept decision to cut the legs out from any player who is new, growing, learning, or trying to figure out if the game is WORTH spending real money on.  It makes 0 sense.  NONE.  AT ALL.

If this isn't fixed in a week, I will uninstall this game and move on w/ my life.  And, if you check the hours I have put into playing, I thoroughly understand the mechanics behind the game as well as the MASSIVE hindrance this change would put into my own ability to play.  And I'm not someone w/ a poor roster just wanting to get a feel for it and decide if it's worth my time and money.

By refusing to let players develop their own style, experiment w/ different characters w/o the feeling that, if they lose, they'll have to wait 2-6 hours before they can play again, this product is going to plunge into the depths of being another 'free-to-play' game which is in NO WAY competitive, fair, enjoyable, or worth our time and money.

People who love this game and play it daily are already dropping out, along w/ their free advertising... New players will be faced w/ unbeatable teams funded by players w/ pockets deep enough to not care, and this MASSIVELY UNAPPEALING wall of dead-time where they can do NOTHING but sit and wait for the game to slowly heal them over a 2-6 hour period.  IT IS PURELY BAFFLING TO NOT BE ABLE TO COMPREHEND HOW AWFUL THIS WILL BE TO ANYONE WHO WANTS TO FALL IN LOVE WITH A GAME.  How do you hope to attract, entertain, and KEEP players playing when you DON'T let them play for hours on end?  NO ONE is going to pay money, to a game, that they have 0 chance of being able to jump in, experiment, and get their feet wet in competition that is so far skewed towards players who buy the best characters and level them up w/o any work cause they can afford it.  Those players, like myself, who have put in HOURS AND HOURS of time learning the game, developing strategies to be able to out-last, out play, and still remain highly competitive with those players who cheat their way up using cash are going to be GONE.

I sincerely hoped this is fixed in the next 7 days, or I will feel so dumb for having invested so much time and energy into a game which doesn't consider 90% of their fan-base when making decisions about how to move their product forward.

Sincerely,

A once loyal and dedicated, and HOPEFULLY FUTURE loyal and dedicated, fan and player.

reviewText:
A surprisingly great match 3 game that has a good story along with all of your favorite Marvel heroes. You can (via collecting in game cards through playing the game, or if you really want, by paying REAL money) play as pretty much anyone in the Marvel universe. Daken? sure. Black Widow (I and II) not a problem! paperbag wearing Spider-Man? Yep, he's there too.

Play the story, or compete against other players teams, the choice is yours! And when your heroes get beaten up and need a  health replenish, either use an in game health pack (you can win them in game or buy them, your choice) or just play another game for an hour while they recharge their batteries, ready for another fight.

It's not a pay to play game, I've put a good few hours into the game and have not spent a penny. If you enjoy match three puzzle games and are looking for something to play to kill a few minutes here and there, you could do a lot worse than Marvel Puzzle Quest.

reviewText: I have been pretty addicted to this game, however I've been playing on my Android phone.  I wish I could link my progress with the PC version. reviewText:
This is a fun, free-to-play take on the Puzzle Quest paradigm set in the Marvel universe with most of its most popular characters.  It is designed for bite-size chunks, and offers a lot of progression both in building up individual characters and in building up your roster giving you new options and new combinations to try out.

There is a lot of noise and anger within the community here on Steam involving a recent change to healing characters that now keeps people from endlessly grinding out events.  I am adding this review primarily to wholeheartedly disagree with their viewpoint.  Before the healing change, I was about ready to give up on the game.  I have played for a while, and my roster was filled out and developed pretty nicely for a mostly-free player (I have spent some real money to expand my roster size faster, but never to get new characters or develop them -- the characters and XP equivalent come pretty quickly as you play so I never felt the need to spend money to accelerate that).  Unfortunately, I could never devote 8 or more hours a day to an event, so I never had a chance to win.  Players would grind out an event with their #1 best team of 3 characters until their health was low, then grind out a PvE level to heal those characters back to max, and then go back to grinding out the event again.  The enemy teams were almost always the three same characters, the winners' total scores were ridiculously high, and I was about done with the game.

Enter the healing change -- any healing during a battle is now temporary to that battle (with a couple of exceptions that can only heal a character back to about 50% of his health).  Now, event winners must play with various combinations of characters and be better at the game (take less damage) than others, rather than simply spend more time than others on the game.  In my mind, this is a significant improvement to the game's health and will make things work much better in the long run.

A final word about a game being 'pay2win' -- For most people, when you think of pay2win games, this references some item that gives a player an advantage that can only be bought with real money, not earned by playing the game.  This game includes NOTHING that fits that category.  There is absolutely nothing in the game that you cannot earn directly by playing the game.  The only reason I spent money on it at all was to support the developers for my time spent and because as a collector I wanted to hold on to all the characters I earned in game (they put a 7-day limit on adding a character to your roster to push for money to be spent there, but even the couple of times I lost a character by not adding them during this limit I have always gotten that character again down the road).  In any event, I only play at most about 10 characters, and I have been placing near the top more and more since this healing change occurred.  For reference, you can get 10 character slots with the free real-money currency you earn within the first month or so of playing.

tl;dr -- This is a fun, well designed game, and the developers are thinking about the long-term health of the game with their decisions.  As in many free-to-play games, you must spend either money or time to advance and succeed, but both are viable options.  Additionally, you will need to play well and be smart with both your match-3 tactics and your roster decision strategies to have the best chance to succeed in the game and its events.  Thanks to the recent controversial change that many others complain about, you no longer need to devote 8+ hours a day during an event to have a chance to succeed.

reviewText: The use of Marvel characters is great, and the core idea of connecting special abilities to matching crystals is just as good now as it was back in the original Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords. But so far enough developers have been able to find new ways to present it that it hasn’t given up the ghost, and it helps when they can hook specific audiences. For comic fans, Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign can definitely do that.Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign does a pretty good job in putting two popular franchises together, and the result is a fun, challenging match-3 puzzle game.

reviewText:
Great game overall, the best one in Puzzle Quest series. If you ever had any interest in Puzzle Quest then look no further.

Characters are closely represented with their respective unique powers, and new heroes are added regularly.

Events and storyline are just perfect for newcomers and casual players, but players who spend more than a couple of hours a day may find it thin and repeating. With the addition of health system, the server load should be guaranteed and the ranking ladders will not be owned by marathon players.

It is truly a free to play game where you have no obligation to spend anything. As for winning, it's down to how much time spent against other players - just like every ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes out there. Money can only help making the characters stronger, not the time needed to complete the matches.

reviewText:
I enjoy match-3 games, and this comes with all of the benefits and drawbacks that come with competitive versions. (Matches aren't timed, but opponents take alternating turns against you, with possibilities for long strings of watching the computer play when it gets a lucky combo.) The game makes full use of 4- and 5-matches, giving each a different bonus, and recognizing T-shaped and L-shaped 5-matches. (Games that don't do this drive me crazy.)

As a free-to-play game, I like that everything in-game is still accessible without purchase. Progression is a bit slower, of course, but it is possible to win hero points" (in-game gold) and expand the slots available for heroes.

The unique elements of this game are two-fold:
1) A collectable card-game like element of choosing which heroes to keep and level up
date:
and which combinations to use in each battle.
2) A chance for gamers not already steeped in superhero lore to get to know Marvel characters and interactions a bit better. It's quickly turning me into a fan!

There are two modes of play: "story mode" and "versus".
* Story mode has in-character intro and outro dialog
recommended: pulling you into a comic storyline. It's a fun way to immerse yourself in the lore of the Marvel universe.\n* Versus mode pits your selection of heroes against heroes from another player's roster. It is worth noting that you are not actually playing the other person
hoursPlayed: but rather the AI using their heroes and abilities. This is a huge positive for me
voteText: because I don't have to deal with connection lags
helpfulPercent: people who afk for long periods
votesHelpful: or trolling in a chat window. But if you're looking to match wits against a human opponent
votesTotal: this might leaving you wanting for more.\n\nOver 40 hours in
votesFunny: this continues to be a deeply engaging game!"

reviewText: I like the concept of Bejeweled and I enjoy Marvel. This game is a failure at both. Want to play a decent amount of rounds? Better pay to intsa-heal the heros multiple times. Want to see a great set of combo matches spawn? We'll let the AI drop that hit instead of you with with broken randoms. I really wanted to enjoy this game but after a while it's too in your face about 'paid benefits'. Good luck if you want to relax and, just maybe, enjoy a casual puzzle game past the first handful of levels.

reviewText: Under normal circumstances, I would say for a free to play like this its not bad. But there is one simple thing that drives me crazy, and that's the fact that you almost never get the covers you're looking for and that enemies get much stronger much faster than you can by simply grinding. I also have had issues where I will make a match, and that'll be it. Then the AI will make a match which leads to a chain of new pieces dropping and making more matches which goes on and on in a chain that I can never seem to match. This is annoying. I am not sure if it's my bad luck or if it's just the way the game is. Either way, the only people that really seem to do well are people who have no life and log mad hours into this game, or the people that don't mind dropping cash into the game in order to get the packs which in my opinion defeats the entire purpose of free-to-play".\n\nIn short
date: while many may enjoy this game and do well in it
recommended: I am not one of those people and cannot bring myself to recommend this game no matter how much I wanted to like it."

reviewText:
Marvel puzzle quest’s game mechanic is amazing. As a fun of puzzle quest, I got hook to this game early on.

However, the pay-to-enjoy aspect kills it for me. The game encourages players to have a large roster of heroes in order to enjoy a specific mission for the week. In order to increase your roster, you need to gain a currency which is acquired through drops from prologue battles, finishing a mission with a high ranking score than other players or purchase it with real money.

Obtaining a hero you want or levelling a hero you have also requires too much time and money. Gaining a 1 or 2 star hero is not a problem. Getting a 3 to 4 star though is a different story. You either have to be lucky at getting a 3 star hero from the standard cover drop, finish a mission with a high ranking score, or use gold to get draw a cover from the mission drop.

reviewText:
I used to love this game, as it should be obvious from how many hours I have sunk into this thing, but the game has made a definite turn for the worst.

It is in the Puzzle Quest style of gameplay with a few tweaks that take some getting used to (team formation, different type of leveling, matching more gems for the free turn, new timers on gems that you want to eliminate/protect with timers, etc).  I would think that if you were a fan of the first couple of Puzzle Quest games then you might enjoy this game as it scratches that same itch.  Most of the adjustments to the gameplay are interesting takes on the old formula, which I think are pleasant.

However, recently the publisher has made the game more of a chore to play than anything.  They are employing several different tactics to try to squeeze more money out of the players, to the point where it has become a hindrance to my enjoyment of the game.  By aggressively trying to find ways to get money by adding new 'features' that limit the playerbase unless you are willing to pay more (and more and more) they have completely destroyed my enjoyment of this game.  I used to recommend this game to my friends, however I can no longer do that and have stopped playing the game myself.

reviewText:
Let me get this out of the way: this is a very nice game. It combines match-3 with cardfight (not sure what they are called) games where you level up your cards. Here you level up your (Marvel) heroes by earning Iso-8 and by earning their skills.
There are events that give you big prices (lots of Iso-8 or recruit tokens for more heroes).

More heroes. That's why I wouldn't recomment this game. You start with roster of 4 heroes. For every extra hero you need to buy an extra slot for Gold. You guessed it, gold is real money.
Four hero slots is nothing. I played less than a day and already had 10 heroes (5 rostered and 5 waiting to be recruited).

If that part of the game was any different or if buying with real money doesn't bother you: play this game. It's nice. Good graphics, nice sound effects, good skills and there's even a storyline.
For me however that's a dealbreaker. You will not progress enough if you do not buy extra roster space.

So...byebye MPQ.

reviewText: Marvel Puzzle Quest is a very fun game.  I downloaded it the day it came out on iOS and I have played the PC Version since beta.  I have been a fan of Puzzle Quest since playing the original on my PSP, and well that plus Marvel really got me interested.  The gameplay is fun, really dig the UI (especially on PC), and there's a fun variety of characters and abilities.  That said, I feel since launch the developers have put in a lot of walls that were not previously there for the sake of them making more money.  I understand that game development is a business and making money is good, but the game was much more fun in previous versions.  That doesn't stop me from playing it like a no good junkie, though.

reviewText:
Fun game, but it feels better suited to tablets and shouldn't have been ported to PC. A lot if issues that other people are having can be lessen by playing in short sessions, such at 10 to 30 minutes at a time, especially with free heroes that the game will give you every few days, as well as cash shop currancy. With this game being on PC, we're acustomed to playing an hour or more, and this game penalizes that without using cash.

One new game mechanic added to the Puzzle Quest system are abilities that effect tiles on the board. Such as Iron Man placing Protect Tiles, that turn the normal gems in to shielded gems to reduce damage to your heroes, or Storm's Attack Tiles that damage your opponent. They still behave like normal gems, in that you can match them to other colors and they'll go away. Some of your enemies also place gems that have a count down timer, and will activate after a number of turns have pasted. Like HAMMER Assassins that will place Sniper Tiles on the board, and will deal heavy damage to your heros after a few turns have passed. This helps you as a player, since you can prevent the enemies abilities by matching those countdown tiles, and removing the ability before it has a chance to go off.

The worst part about this game, is that when your heroes are damaged or knocked out in a game, they will have to recover and this can take up to an hour or more without using heal packs. You start out with a dozen or so, but once you run out, you'll have to pay cash for more. Also, improving your hero is terrible. Instead of earning experience in battles, you earn this ISO-8 currancy, and you spend that on heroes to improve their base health and a few other stats. To improve their abilities, you have to either spend a ton of the premium currancy or hope that you get another copy of that hero. Say you have Captain America, and he only has one ability. To unlock his other 2 abilities, you'll need another Captain America, with that ability, and add his to your hero. It requires too much luck to improve just one hero, and Puzzle Quest's bosses are betting that will pay tons of money to do so.

Yes, this game has a lot of options to get ahead with cash purchases, and these purchases won't go very far, since most of them are completely random. Say you really want Spider-man on your team, then you have to option of fighting Venom to win a Spider-man with a Fantastic Four suit or throw a few dollars at random hero packs and pray he turns up.

I do recommend this game for tablets, since it's best suit to short play sessions.

reviewText:
Very fun, and not very pay-to-win like all the reviews say.

The PvE story roughly follows the Dark Reign comics, with Norman Osborn, the Green Goblin, creating the subtlely-named Dark Avengers, of which Bullseye is the best by far, in order to do something for someone, I don't know. He is opposed by Iron Man, Black Widow, Storm, Hawkeye, Wolverine, and Thor. It ends with a fairly high level boss fight, which can be easily beaten with stuns or heal abuse because it's a three-on-one curbstomp.

After that, you can go through weekly events against other players to earn more ISO-8, which is your experience, or Hero Points, which can get you more slots for more characters. Most of these events have restrictions or characters that get bonuses in stats, encouraging you to use them in your team and keep the characters you're not as interested in.

I haven't seen the pay-to-win much in my time of playing. Even if you buy ISO-8 and Hero Points, you're still going to have to keep up against people who have more experience with their characters than you and can set up teams with better gem coverage. And even if you get a full party of rare characters, they don't all work together as well as the lower level characters, and many of the three star characters have weaknesses to their powers, such as Iron Man Model 40's Recharge, which provides gems to use on other attacks, but stuns Iron Man for two turns.

Overall, I enjoy this a good bit, and recommend it to others.

reviewText: Certainly a pay to win game, there’s no doubt about that, however the game still offers a fun and challenging experience by not even paying at all. You can still experience the full game without spending a dime; all you need is patience and skill. The game may have a dull story but the gameplay of solving puzzles and collecting characters is highly addictive and entertaining. The best aspect of MPQ:DR is that you don’t need to play it a lot in a day; just having a 30 minute session can get you tonnes of rewards and still build a decent team without having to even look at any micro transactions. Overall, I find the game very fun to play and it’s great to burn a few hours a week with addictive and enjoyable puzzle solving. 8/10

reviewText:
I used to love this game, as it should be obvious from how many hours I have sunk into this thing, but the game has made a definite turn for the worst.

It is in the Puzzle Quest style of gameplay with a few tweaks that take some getting used to (team formation, different type of leveling, matching more gems for the free turn, new timers on gems that you want to eliminate/protect with timers, etc).  I would think that if you were a fan of the first couple of Puzzle Quest games then you might enjoy this game as it scratches that same itch.  Most of the adjustments to the gameplay are interesting takes on the old formula, which I think are pleasant.

However, recently the publisher has made the game more of a chore to play than anything.  They are employing several different tactics to try to squeeze more money out of the players, to the point where it has become a hindrance to my enjoyment of the game.  By aggressively trying to find ways to get money by adding new 'features' that limit the playerbase unless you are willing to pay more (and more and more) they have completely destroyed my enjoyment of this game.  I used to recommend this game to my friends, however I can no longer do that and have stopped playing the game myself.

reviewText:
Okay, so this clearly isn't a Triple A title but it can still be good right? Right?

The answer is no. It isn't. It has good elements of fun. It's fairly entertaining as you gather new heroes, upgrade the ones you like, have cool and sometimes very useful special attacks. So what's the issue then? It's boring and poorly made.

Well first off, the game is basically a Mobile Game ported to PC without ANY of the things a PC port should have. It doesn't have a resolution that would be fitting for a PC and instead looks like you're playing a Tablet game on your monitor. While that may not sound that bad, I've noticed even some of the UI choices are still touch screen like. It overall feels down right aweful to look at for extended periods of time.

Next is the gameplay itself, it's very barebones as the best animations you will see is the little Gems going POOF from chain completions. The special attacks consit of your character of choice flying into the center of the screen and waggling a bit with some flashing lights and sounds.

Once you figure out if you can enjoy the gameplay or not comes the ways you upgrade your heroes. It's basically random lottery as you have to get another copy of your hero to upgrade their skills, after which you then need to use ISO-8 the magical nonsense item to then increase their level. You also can only have so many heroes before you need to purchase more slots. Now that isn't too bad as it's normal, the problem is you can only use what is basically a Money" currency which is limited as you only get some per day unless you wish to pay for it. The same currency is used for pretty much everything and they will try their damnedest to get you to waste it on heroes
hoursPlayed: etc. Then they shoehorn in some Healing character nonsense that basically ripped off from Facebook games.\n\nThe story missions try ever so hard to entertain and keep you interested but the lack of voices
voteText: new images and basically an interesting story that hasn't been heard over and over again
helpfulPercent: brings it down on its knees. The more interesting and rewarding stories are locked out until you play and gather Strong/OP heroes. It's not even recommended that you try them WHATSOEVER until you're very well off into the game as they will not only stomp you out but cause you to need "Health packs" just to recover and continue playing the game. The next part of story missions is that they often can be replayed for different loot
votesHelpful: the problem is even though it says 1/4 things to be looted you can still gain something that ISN'T an option as loot. I've gotten ISO-20 which wasn't an option instead of ISO-100 or another Iron Man. When all you do is want to have 4/4 in loot and you have to replay the same
votesTotal: easy

it gets very boring.

The art direction is okay at best; you have art work that doesn't look the best on these big screens as it's made for much smaller ones. reviewText:
Whether you will like this game depends on what you are looking for in it. Most of the criticism of this game revolves around the 'pay to win' accusations, and in a sense they're true, you're unlikely to win most of the main events if you don't sink some money into buying new heroes, health packs or slots for new heroes, so if you're the kind of person who wants to open it up and play for hours non-stop without paying a thing this game will likely frustrate you.

For me I didn't want to spend much on this game, I've spent a total of £6 after 100 hours playing and I don't intend to spend anymore. When I play I'm not in a rush and am happy to slowly build up my heroes over time, I play in shorter bursts to do certain events and can play in windowed mode to rotate it around with other things. Some people get annoyed because if you lose and have run out of health packs the only way to get more is to buy them or wait to win more in certain events.

As for the actual gameplay, there's not much to say. You pick three of your heroes against opposition and match the colours up to best suit the abilities of your selected heroes. It's puzzlequest and free to try out if you're unsure. Also note that for the multiplayer you are not actually playing against other people, it is against three of their heroes that the ai controls.

reviewText: Marvel Puzzle Quest is a very fun game.  I downloaded it the day it came out on iOS and I have played the PC Version since beta.  I have been a fan of Puzzle Quest since playing the original on my PSP, and well that plus Marvel really got me interested.  The gameplay is fun, really dig the UI (especially on PC), and there's a fun variety of characters and abilities.  That said, I feel since launch the developers have put in a lot of walls that were not previously there for the sake of them making more money.  I understand that game development is a business and making money is good, but the game was much more fun in previous versions.  That doesn't stop me from playing it like a no good junkie, though.

reviewText:
Marvel Puzzle Quest is a tipical block combining game that adds to the game the marvel universe/heroes to give some diversity and fun collecting/leveling the heroes.

Every heroe has diferent habilities and you can fight in 3v3 battles combining the strenghts of your heroes to progress through the game. You start with 3 basic heroes after doing the tutorial and you have to manage to lvl up using the ISO points you obtain by winning battles. Some battles on the campaign gives you extra heroes or hero points (hero points are the ones you need to have extra slots for more heroes).

Its a bit slow at the beginning because every time a hero takes damages, it needs time to restore his hp, so whe you have only 3 heroes it can be a bit slow to advance. But as soon as you have 5+ heroes and reach lvl 10+ with some of them, you can keep playing almost indefinitly without having to spend real money on the game. Paying real money on this game only gives you a faster progression, but you can manage to do everything just by playing the game.

If you like puzzle games its worth to try this one, just have in mind the first few hours are a bit slow if you dont invest real money.

reviewText:
Very fun, and not very pay-to-win like all the reviews say.

The PvE story roughly follows the Dark Reign comics, with Norman Osborn, the Green Goblin, creating the subtlely-named Dark Avengers, of which Bullseye is the best by far, in order to do something for someone, I don't know. He is opposed by Iron Man, Black Widow, Storm, Hawkeye, Wolverine, and Thor. It ends with a fairly high level boss fight, which can be easily beaten with stuns or heal abuse because it's a three-on-one curbstomp.

After that, you can go through weekly events against other players to earn more ISO-8, which is your experience, or Hero Points, which can get you more slots for more characters. Most of these events have restrictions or characters that get bonuses in stats, encouraging you to use them in your team and keep the characters you're not as interested in.

I haven't seen the pay-to-win much in my time of playing. Even if you buy ISO-8 and Hero Points, you're still going to have to keep up against people who have more experience with their characters than you and can set up teams with better gem coverage. And even if you get a full party of rare characters, they don't all work together as well as the lower level characters, and many of the three star characters have weaknesses to their powers, such as Iron Man Model 40's Recharge, which provides gems to use on other attacks, but stuns Iron Man for two turns.

Overall, I enjoy this a good bit, and recommend it to others.

reviewText: If you have any interest in super heroes, and collecting stuff then this game is for you. Don't heed people who say it's micro transactions galore. You can play without paying. Everyday there are several multiplayer events in which you can participate for free and win lots of Iso-8 and HP (game's more valuable other currency) if you are successful enough. There is also a huge single player campaign with lots of rewards. I don't know what people are complaining about. There is one thing though. If you are very competitive then you might feel you need to pay to get ahead of others. It will only save you game play time. Others will catch up to you if you pay, but it will take a while. Since I enjoy the game as it is and I'm a casual gamer at heart, I enjoy it a lot.\n\nThe game is addictive. I also played old Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords. I had enjoyed that one though I didn't finish it. This is a bit different from that one in how leveling works and the fact that you don't have a single character to play with. From what I heard, game's support team is very efficient. I didn't have any problems with the game so far though.

Cons:

reviewText: Are there microtransactions? Yes. Will you need to spend money? A little at the start to get yourself some more room for new heroes. Will you have to continue spending money and be slowly drained to death by mobile gaming business practices?  No. I spent $30 in total.. have 65 roster slots out of the 91. There are lots of ways to earn the currency over time. Patience is your friend. The first month or two will be a little stressful because of the roster situation, if you like their twist on match 3 and enjoy match 3 games.. then it is worth $20 to get those roster slots and free up some pressure.\n\nThe only real complaint with the game is that you can NOT expect to play it whenever you feel like it. It is a mobile game after all, meant to occupy 30mins to an hour of your day every like 8-12 hours. There is a few missions that you can play just for laughs, but once you get all the rewards out of them the only things left to do are competitive PVE and PVP event, and the Deadpool Daily (which is all I really do anymore) which doesn't force you to compete for points against other players. They need more content like Deadpool's Daily.

reviewText:
I'm not one to be suckered in my free games usually, but having enjoyed games like Bejewelled and Puzzle Quest in the past, I figured I'd give it a try. At first, I played a few times, and then stopped playing for a few months as I wasn't sure if it was really my thing or not. I'm not sure what made me decide to try it again one day, but as you can no doubt tell from the hours I've got recorded playing this game, I kinda liked it... just a little ;) It's likely that it was the whole 'feemium' thing that turned me off to start, but this game is generous enough to make you want to keep playing without NEEDING to spend money.

I've never been a comic fanatic or anything, but I've always enjoyed the characters from the Marvel universe, and loved watching the old cartoons like X-Men.
Over the years I've been playing this game, I have spent the odd bit of cash here and there, but I don't think the amount I've spent would only come to around $30 I'd say.

The team at D3 are continually adding new features and characters which keep my interest, and I am a member of an alliance with a group of firends who play, which makes it a little more fun, being able to discuss things with the group. It also allows you to get extra bonuses, as when your alliance members do well in events, the whole alliance will get rewards.

This is a great game to play while having my morning coffee, as it's quick, yet rewarding, but at times during certain events, can be brutally difficult (Damn ninjas!! *shakes fist*). It wouldn't be much fun if it was a walk in the park though!
It's also great that they have daily events, which keeps me coming back to see what's new and what else I can get! (This unlocks after you've played through a certain amount of the single player, so don't give up too soon!)

If you've ever played match 3 games, and enjoyed them, I can't recommend this one highly enough. Building up an ever expanding roster of characters as fun as the game itself!
In my opinion, it's by far the best of all the Puzzle Quest games that have been released, and I even though I have spent many years playing this game, I can't see myself stopping any time soon!

reviewText:
Okay, let's not kid around: This is a barely-adapted port of a mobile game.
For the PC port, I can't say the development team went far to optimise it and I won't comment too much on it.

However, for the game itself, I just started playing this a day ago but it's pretty damn cool and there's so much to do and collect. It's awesome.
I can't say how long the fun will last, but I do love the whole setup of the game.
You collect comic book covers and currency to unlock characters and abilities, you can join your friends in a team online and everyone apparently gets bonuses for members of the team playing the game.

My only frustration (as with most mobile-related games nowadays) is the time-based restriction of progress and unlockables (I haven't gotten far enough in the game to be sure about this, but I think this is seems like the only easy way to consistently get coins/tokens to unlock slots in your roster. You need this to add new members to your team.). Naturally, you're able to get past these restrictions with microtransactions.
Fair enough, if these restrictions weren't in place, every dedicated player would have the strongest possible team in no time. I just wish there was a way to constantly progress without thinking about using real-world money.

Aaaanyway, overall, this game is really fun and I'm enjoying it so far.
Let's go with 8/10.
-1 for the crappy mobile port that still says tap" instead of "click"
and -1 because of the constant need for patience and/or microtransactions if you wanna get everything in the game."

reviewText:
I think I've given the game a decent chance. It is kind of hard to rate, though; it's fun enough to play casually, but it makes casual play difficult with its problematic scaling that so often doesn't work and a level system that is completely dysfunctional.

It really tries super-hard for microtransactions, which I understand are helpful to the developers, but good grief. When the game itself is made less fun and, more importantly, less functional for the sake of encouraging pay-to-win (or at least, pay to have more of a fun game), I feel there has been a fundamental failure.

If a game, in and of itself, is fun, microtransactions can enhance that. But the most crucial part where Marvel Puzzle Quest falls short is that the game so often isn't fun, with a frequently cheap AI, problematic scaling algorithm, and restrictions and level-locking everywhere you look.

There are many characters to choose from, which is very appealing, and the art and animations are great for what they are. Unfortunately this also is a double-edged sword, since you'll unquestionably find yourself up against the old and familiar obstacle of never really getting characters you want -- and being unable to just buy the specific character you do, even with real money -- and instead getting no end of characters you really don't.

I really wish Marvel Puzzle Quest had a more casual play option, but everything is geared to encourage" you to spend real money on making the game a more fun experience

reviewText: Marvel Puzzle Quest is effective at generating a false sense of achievement.  There are many different metrics by which you can make easy, regular progress.  Acquiring new characters, levelling them up, progressing through story missions, and reaching new reward tiers during the events all make it feel like your are gaining something.  Ultimately, though, it feels like a continuous grind with no real end goal.  Like many micro-transaction based games, it is more interesting to see how far you can progress without making a purchase than to buy either of their in-game currencies, so this may truely be a free-to-play game for you.

reviewText:
Horrible, Greedy, Lopsided Game
I want to like this game. I want to like it so much. And there are times I do. This is a rant, pure and simple.

And then the overhwleming amount of the time I see it for the money grab it is. One battle where the underpowered AI pulls off a random cascade of combos puts my strongest characters out for three hours and there is nothing I can do.

I can't wain tournaments to get 2 star, 3 star or 4 star characters because I'm put in tournaments with people who have strong characters. Even if I do manage to win one, I then have to wait for my heroes to heal. And in that time I'm attacked so many times I'm back to no points in the tournament.

I'll admit I have no life recently, so I've spent a whole day trying to get to the top in an event. And it just isn't possible. While I can devote every hour, I will always lose to someone with a few high level 3 stars who is put in the same event as me.

It must be really fun for someone who has a lot of money, because as soon as you have good characters, the game rewards you with more through the tournaments and events. I'm beginning to see that no matter how long I play, I will always be behind because the devs give no chance for me to catch up. Those who already have 3 star characters are pulling away and getting more. By the time I have one, who I can decently level with covers, they will have 20.

And why can't we turn covers into a free level for our character, rather than have to sell them? I'm sick of getting the same 1 star cover for characters with maxed powers. The only rewards I can get are standard tokens, so at least make them useful in some way.

reviewText: The game was fun when I started playing it.  It required strategy to beat some matchups with Wolverine and Thor.  It was possible to beat almost anyone at the same level as you with even the basic three characters of Storm, Black Widow, and Iron Man. Even tougher enemies were no problem if you had boosts. Boosts were availavble for cheap in game currency of ISO-8 which you easily can get playing any level.  Only two of them required the premium currency of coins.  Now boosts have doubled in Iso-8 price and even more of them require coins to purchase.  The developers have totally changed it to pay to win.  Check the number 1 ranked people in the tournaments and see if how many of their people are three star level 133 characters that just came out a week ago.

reviewText: Fun puzzle game elements, but there seems to be a strong pay to win aspect. The core gameplay is fun, but the pvp events seem to favor those who choose to drop large amounts of money, or have devoted an insane amount of time. Levelling the characters can be frustrating because of how little iso8, akak xp, you get after completing past levels and even new levels. The event PVE's do off good rewards though. Allowing you to get recruit tokens of varying types somewhat easily. There seems to be a decent amount of hackers though. Players who have thousands of points in the event with low level characters pop up fairly often and it can be frustrating.\n\nGameplay wise: It is fun to play in quick bursts, but the leveling and hero acquisition can be frustrating. Pay to win is a little too obvious. Otherwise, I find it fun to play, but I try and take breaks otherwise I get frustrated.

reviewText: At first this game was fun and addicting, I played it on Steam, and then I got it on my Android phone too. Eventually, the problems started like being a free to play game, it's built around the concept of spending money now or wait a while. Early on, you can get through the levels and it's fun, but as you get into the game, you'll notice that your heroes take damage in the puzzle battles, so you can wait like 15 minutes for one guy to heal, so ok go and use your other Avengers. The further you get, the more the waiting times add up, and the game wants you to buy health packs with real money. It also doesn't carry over from version to version so if you did spend money on microtransactions on Steam, it wouldn't show up on a mobile version that you own. It's a big waste of time, and potentially money if you go that route. It doesn't offer a great deal of free content before it tries every last resort to bleed you for money.

reviewText:
There's a pretty severe proviso on this game.

You may need to spend a smidge money. Not to buy cards, but to buy card slots. You can win a lot of the in-game currency, and once your decks are strong enough you can get more. Events allow you access to even more, but if you don't have enough slots you can't capitalise on the randomness of the card drops. They've set a week's lifetime on any card drop before it decays, so if you're willing to lose cards while you farm the currency then don't spend a cent.

It's not a bad game by any means, but it takes a lot to get off the ground and start winning successively and consecutively. If you're a bit timerich and waiting on some new releases not the worst thing you could play. But don't spend more than $20 on it.

reviewText: Addictive, free to play, jewel matching. Hero powers and damage variation of colors help add an element of stratgey to the board play. reviewText:
For the first couple of days I played this game I was a little frustrated.  It seemed that the items were very overpriced (and they are), and that I couldn't get anything I wanted.  However, If you are smart at how you spend your money, use your items, and which characters you play, you can do very well in this game with little or no cash.  The real game is in the PvP, which isn't PvP at all really.  The Prologue, is just that, a starting to the real game.  Once you get 3 characters around 25-30 you can actually start playing the game which is all in building various teams who's abilities compliment each other.  I started out with Iron Man Model 35, Storm Modern, and Black Widow Modern.  This team will take you very far.  Now the anchor of my team is Black Widow Original.  She can heal and steal AP so I almost always end a fight with full health.  She does very well with Wolverine or Thor.  As you can see I've spent many hours playing this game on my PC (although half or more was probably AFK time.)  I've spent $10 on this game and I've felt it was a good choice.  My husband also plays and he spent $5.  We both spent the money to buy hero coins which we used to open slots for more characters. You will need at least 12 to get started and I currently have 18. 18 slots is enough to keep my favorites.  I never felt the need or pressure to buy for anything else.

A note on the PvP, you get to choose who you play.  If you don't like the team, press skip, and you will be presented with another choice.  You can find teams you can beat at any level and since the very dumb AI is controlling the opposing team you can generally beat teams much higher level with smart play.  You get either 70 or 140 ISO-8 for every match you win, and you should be winning nearly all of them since you get to choose who you fight.  With an average of 105 ISO-8  per match and matches lasting about 3 minutes  you can level up characters very quickly in RPG terms.  However it probably seems slow for a casual mobile app.  You get points in tournaments based on the ranking of the team you fight, not their level, so with smart picks and persistence you can rank well and get good rewards early on, but if you have to come in first, you're going to have to work hard and wait a long time.  In addition to the end of tournament rewards, there are frequently progression rewards which you get regardless of your final ranking.  As there are frequently multiple tournaments hapening simultaneously and shield trainer always available, even after you've exhauseted the story line rewards there is always plenty to do and more characters to collect.

I find Marvel Puzzle Quest fun and surprisingly addictive, yet not at all pay to win.  In fact, the items are so expensive that several hundred dollars wouldn't get you very far. So those who do spend mony don't have any real advantage beyond saving a few minutes.  In summary, if you can get over the slow grind to level 30, this game really takes off and becomes much more fun.  Don't spend hero coins or money on anything other than opening up more roster slots until you fully understand what you are getting in return (i.e. hardly anthing). Participate in the tournaments early and often as this is where the ISO-8 you need to level your characters comes from even if you don't place well.  I'm not surprised that the people who only played an hour don't like it, though.  It's not really a play for a few minutes kinda game.  It's much better suited to long sessions on the PC.  It's the most fun I've had for $10 in a while.

reviewText:
I read most of the reviews, and saw how negative people were because of the microtransactions. Having tried the game, I can say that even though there is a lot of microtransactions, they do not restrict you in any way. So far, I have been able to get most things just by playing, and have been awarded a decent amount of coins just because of playing. Of course, you won't be able to own everything by playing, but you also don't have to buy anything.

As far as gameplay goes, the game offers a fine experience, some strategy, and a lot of puzzling, and I find myself enjoying it, especially considering that it's free.

The best thing I can say is that you try the game yourself and see if you think that microtransactions bother you or not. In my opinion, I think they are not and that you can enjoy this game decently without paying anything.

reviewText:
There's a pretty severe proviso on this game.

You may need to spend a smidge money. Not to buy cards, but to buy card slots. You can win a lot of the in-game currency, and once your decks are strong enough you can get more. Events allow you access to even more, but if you don't have enough slots you can't capitalise on the randomness of the card drops. They've set a week's lifetime on any card drop before it decays, so if you're willing to lose cards while you farm the currency then don't spend a cent.

It's not a bad game by any means, but it takes a lot to get off the ground and start winning successively and consecutively. If you're a bit timerich and waiting on some new releases not the worst thing you could play. But don't spend more than $20 on it.

reviewText: Addictive, free to play, jewel matching. Hero powers and damage variation of colors help add an element of stratgey to the board play. The RPG elements of collecting heroes, leveling them, and building the best team combination are the driving motivation. The story and delivery are nothing great, but what are you really expecting from this type of gameplay? The down time (hero recovery) period can be frustrating sometimes, especially when just starting. There are always events and tournaments happening that are enjoyable and can provide great rewards. Overall, this game is a great pass time and does NOT require any real money to advance (as so many reviews claim), have spent $0 and havent had any issues. 8/10

reviewText:
For the first couple of days I played this game I was a little frustrated.  It seemed that the items were very overpriced (and they are), and that I couldn't get anything I wanted.  However, If you are smart at how you spend your money, use your items, and which characters you play, you can do very well in this game with little or no cash.  The real game is in the PvP, which isn't PvP at all really.  The Prologue, is just that, a starting to the real game.  Once you get 3 characters around 25-30 you can actually start playing the game which is all in building various teams who's abilities compliment each other.  I started out with Iron Man Model 35, Storm Modern, and Black Widow Modern.  This team will take you very far.  Now the anchor of my team is Black Widow Original.  She can heal and steal AP so I almost always end a fight with full health.  She does very well with Wolverine or Thor.  As you can see I've spent many hours playing this game on my PC (although half or more was probably AFK time.)  I've spent $10 on this game and I've felt it was a good choice.  My husband also plays and he spent $5.  We both spent the money to buy hero coins which we used to open slots for more characters. You will need at least 12 to get started and I currently have 18. 18 slots is enough to keep my favorites.  I never felt the need or pressure to buy for anything else.

A note on the PvP, you get to choose who you play.  If you don't like the team, press skip, and you will be presented with another choice.  You can find teams you can beat at any level and since the very dumb AI is controlling the opposing team you can generally beat teams much higher level with smart play.  You get either 70 or 140 ISO-8 for every match you win, and you should be winning nearly all of them since you get to choose who you fight.  With an average of 105 ISO-8  per match and matches lasting about 3 minutes  you can level up characters very quickly in RPG terms.  However it probably seems slow for a casual mobile app.  You get points in tournaments based on the ranking of the team you fight, not their level, so with smart picks and persistence you can rank well and get good rewards early on, but if you have to come in first, you're going to have to work hard and wait a long time.  In addition to the end of tournament rewards, there are frequently progression rewards which you get regardless of your final ranking.  As there are frequently multiple tournaments hapening simultaneously and shield trainer always available, even after you've exhauseted the story line rewards there is always plenty to do and more characters to collect.

I find Marvel Puzzle Quest fun and surprisingly addictive, yet not at all pay to win.  In fact, the items are so expensive that several hundred dollars wouldn't get you very far. So those who do spend mony don't have any real advantage beyond saving a few minutes.  In summary, if you can get over the slow grind to level 30, this game really takes off and becomes much more fun.  Don't spend hero coins or money on anything other than opening up more roster slots until you fully understand what you are getting in return (i.e. hardly anthing). Participate in the tournaments early and often as this is where the ISO-8 you need to level your characters comes from even if you don't place well.  I'm not surprised that the people who only played an hour don't like it, though.  It's not really a play for a few minutes kinda game.  It's much better suited to long sessions on the PC.  It's the most fun I've had for $10 in a while.

reviewText:
Originally it was a moderately entertaining F2P game that was still enjoyable without spending much real money on. The in game economy was always horribly broken. The 100 to 1 Hero Point ratio was not bad, but what it bought you was ridiculous. For an example unlocking one level of a skill in a three star(Rare) character is 1250 HP. Or $12.50. They want $12.50 to unlock one level of one skill of which there are 13 per character. Or around $150 if you want to completely unlock one character.

Fine, I was happy to play alound with the covers I could get through tournament rewards and the daily drops. Then came along the latest patch. Instead of fixing the rampant cheating or other various broken portions of the game, they decide to nerf some of the better characters that are relatively easy for the free players to get. No Devs, they weren't overpowered, they were accessible and most of the other accessible characters suck. Again, nerfing happens, most devs have still yet to realize it's better to balance up than down, but any relatively experienced gamer is used to that. But they also decided to start charging HP for the +3AP to all boost. They're now charging the equivalent of $1 for a stack of three boosts that will last maybe 10 to 15 minutes of game time and is very necessary for the casual players. The devs basically too a look at the game stats, saw what the casual players used most, and either made them less effective or started charging for them.

I had intended on buying $15 or so worth of HP to support the game and buy some roster slots, but I am definitely glad I waited and they will now never see a dime from me.

reviewText:
Interesting twist on bejeweled

The game play was mostly intuitive, although how exactly the enemies move/fight back is not very obvious, as there are different types of enemies that use different game mechanics to fight you. Also, choosing which ally is in front isn't very obvious either, even tho it's critical sometimes to know exactly who's in the front line and who will get the hit.

This game, being free to play, has a leveling system that requires coins, which you can buy in the in-game store or otherwise purchase with real money. I'm not a big fan of free to play games for this reason, so it took away from my enjoyment of the game.

The art and animations are pretty good, and the storyline" is ok for a Marvel storyline. It's mostly just a big excuse to put all the Marvel characters together
date: but it does enough to provide a background for the game.\n\nOnly not recommending this game because I dislike free to play. However
recommended: it is a solid bejeweled spin-off other than that."

reviewText:
The most fundamental problems with this game are:

1) While Free To Play doesn't always equal Pay To Win etc, the main problem with this title is that they give you a heap of extra random characters (and in fact specific ones too!) as rewards, but you can't keep them without paying money... and the rewards have a time limit.  You are able to win some of the precious purchasable tokens as rewards, but nowhere near enough to keep up with the characters you receive.

2) While the game lets you play on a variety of places, and in fact makes you sign up with a random external system... there are no in game links to the external system, and they seem to have removed the ability for this Steam version to properly synch with the other devices. I believe some people can and have done this, but either it's been removed from this version, or if you didn't immediately agree then your one opportuniy to do this is never repeated.

3) Lack of in-game support.  Sure - everyone who has played PQ or even anything like it knows the basics.  And there is a tutorial mode which is ridiculously hand-holding, but... later when you want to look up stupid technical things, it is quite difficult to navigate.

4) Everything suddenly gets tied to PvP, which causes everything to be heavily Pay to Win.  There's not enough story of appropriate level to keep people playing on a PvE level... so you either fork out cash to level, or you ... stop playing?

Problem: I love superheroes.  I love Puzzle Quest.  This... is... almost? ish? what people should expect from a free-to-play game that works on phones and tablets (at least these days) but I have objections to games that make you stop playing them as a game mechanic... especially on a PC.  Sorry - it's a stupid design.

reviewText:
Although it incorporates many of the mechanics from its namesake, and art/characters from its theme, the game seems to lack depth and character development, instead relying on grinding or payment for character progression.

The character artwork looks nice in combat as well as cutscenes, and the party system with character based skills is interesting with a good amount of variety, using the puzzle quest style of gameplay. This is overshadowed by the unfortunate fact that you will most likely not get access to all of the character skills and upgrades without grinding or paying for 'hero tokens', or hoping that an upcoming event has a chance to win an upgrade for your preferred character. As the difficulty increases you may need to ditch interesting low level characters for random high level ones just to keep up with the stat scaling.

With better RPG and leveling elements I could recommend it, otherwise it feels like a chore to upgrade the characters you enjoy.

reviewText:
I like Puzzle Games.  I like levlling up characters.  I like the Marvel Universe.  D3 are utter, utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S for creating a game that's akin to crystal meth.  It's free to play, and it's possible to actually play F2P without spending a real penny, but it WILL take you longer to level characters up, and get into the meatier parts of the game (The Tournaments).

The prologue is decent, and a good intro into how the game is run/played.  But once that's done, what else is there to do?  Well, there's usually a weekly tournament to partake it, which can give you rare characters/abilities if you're good enough to hold your coveted position at the top of the tables.  Even if you don't, there's still rewards for just taking part, which I think actually helps the life span of the game.  Admittedly, I've spent a fair few pounds on the game, but I've ditched every MMO now so spending a little on a game that I would have paid full price for isn't bad at all.

Now, one more go...

reviewText: if you've ever played puzzle quest (1,2, kindgoms or galactrix, idk if there are others) then you'll find the gameplay similar (swap stones to match 3 vertically/horizontaly to cause damage to opponent & gain resources used to employ secondary abilities). this iteration of the series strongly borrows from free-to-play mmos/facebook games in the form of microtransactions. characters are upgraded through cards purchased through in-game currency which is gained through rewards for completeting missions or events, or bought through the in-game shop. it also suppliments the typical puzzle quest battle system with a 3v3 marvel vs capcom style team fight, which adds another level of complexity to the game.\ndisregarding the whole play-to-win aspect, the game itself is fun, with great artwork and an interesting variety of iconic marvel characters. at times i find the pace a bit sluggish for a casual game, and the difficulty can sometimes spike unexpectedly, but overall it is a very fun game, without needing a huge investment of time to be fun.

reviewText: At first this game was fun and addicting, I played it on Steam, and then I got it on my Android phone too. Eventually, the problems started like being a free to play game, it's built around the concept of spending money now or wait a while. Early on, you can get through the levels and it's fun, but as you get into the game, you'll notice that your heroes take damage in the puzzle battles, so you can wait like 15 minutes for one guy to heal, so ok go and use your other Avengers. The further you get, the more the waiting times add up, and the game wants you to buy health packs with real money. It also doesn't carry over from version to version so if you did spend money on microtransactions on Steam, it wouldn't show up on a mobile version that you own. It's a big waste of time, and potentially money if you go that route. It doesn't offer a great deal of free content before it tries every last resort to bleed you for money.

reviewText: Fun puzzle game elements, but there seems to be a strong pay to win aspect. The core gameplay is fun, but the pvp events seem to favor those who choose to drop large amounts of money, or have devoted an insane amount of time. Levelling the characters can be frustrating because of how little iso8, akak xp, you get after completing past levels and even new levels. The event PVE's do off good rewards though. Allowing you to get recruit tokens of varying types somewhat easily. There seems to be a decent amount of hackers though. Players who have thousands of points in the event with low level characters pop up fairly often and it can be frustrating.\n\nGameplay wise: It is fun to play in quick bursts, but the leveling and hero acquisition can be frustrating. Pay to win is a little too obvious. Otherwise, I find it fun to play, but I try and take breaks otherwise I get frustrated.

reviewText: This isn't a bad way to burn some time, and players *can* get a good experience out of the game without spending money.  Free players may not be able to compete with the top players (which may or may not be all right as far as some players are concerned),  but they can still enjoy themselves if inability to compete at top tier doesn't trouble them too much.\n\nThere is a pattern of finish a timed quest, use the rewards to do the next timed quest, use the rewards from that to help the next timed quest, etc. etc. that is very relentless.  If you're a completionist, be aware you can never complete" things.  There's always something else to do.  (This is a plus for some players

recommended: and are completely fine with letting rewards from limited time quests slip by
hoursPlayed: then this game is one you should pick up.\n\nI left the game for a time because I was tired of grinding for rewards.  The game can be played enjoyably without feeling the compulsion to grind if you can ignore the rewards system

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/peuv1rJhS7Q

The premise is straightforward, match color gems to earn energy to fuel your team's special attacks.  Four clears a row, while five grants an extra turn.

Teams are built up of three unique characters that you invest currency into to increase their power.  It can be daunting at first to jump into a F2P game, there is always that flashing notification to encourage you to spend money.

However, Marvel Puzzle Quest is balanced well that if you choose to spend time over money you will find a good amount of success.

reviewText:
Key notes here:  1:  The cash shop is pretty hard in this game, and new players will feel left out if they can not get into an alliance.

That said.  If your alliance can rank in the top 500 or so consistently you can all but avoid the cash shop with all the free goods and recruit tokens you can earn.

Taco vault 10 packs are super good if you wont want to drop 50 bucks for a 40 pack.  Team slots are point efficent untill you can only get single slots, and even then you do need alot of them.

EVEN WITH THAT!  I love the smooth intuitve game play (well, as intuitive as a tile matching game gets)  there is a good sense of balance when you go against equally ranked teams.  And best of all, it is mostly effort that wins.

reviewText:
It's a match-3 puzzle game that lets you bring your choice of characters, each with their own special abilities, into the match. Depending on the characters, rules will be altered or added to that will alter how the match plays and can have a massive effect on the outcome of matches.

Damage suffered is per-hero. Damage carries over between matches, so you can barely win one match and start another only to lose after your first turn if you don't wait for any suffered damage to your heroes to be restored. You can pay real world currency to hurry the healing along, but there's no requirement to do so.

The publisher makes money from a cash shop, selling healing items, hero roster space, and random hero draws. You can get more heroes and ingame shop currency from playing the game, but even paying players feel an inventory squeeze if they're even slightly packrat-like.

Think Puzzle Quest with a mostly optional microtransaction business model.

reviewText: This is one of the most elegant, amazing, match 3 RPGS I've ever played. I've played it pretty much every day for 18 months now - way more hours than Skyrim, Mass Effect and Borderlands put together. Spending cash simply speeds up your level gain. I've dropped cash on this, and happily so - hell I paid for those last three games. The devs don't always hit home runs out of the gate when they release new ideas(who does?), but they're great about updating and improving the game and actively solving problems. The art is great if you're a huge comic fan. Highly, highly recommendeed.

reviewText:
I've played this game for roughly two years on the iPad & iPhone, and although I've taken a few breaks, I generally play it every day.  I find it to be a somewhat repetitive but still enjoyable game.  Mechanically the battles are done using a match-3 mechanic, like a bejeweled game.  It's not hard, but I'd say it's more challenging than Candy Crush or other similar games.  The tricky part is that there's a paper-rock-sissors element to the characters, and you need to match enough a certain color gem to enable a hero's power to be used.  Like many other free-to-play games, there are two currencies, one common and another rare.  (plus a third, command points, which was recently introduced and can unlock much stronger four or five star characters).

The real key to success in this game is patience and persistance.  It's somewhat pay to win, but the truth is that I'd say it's pay-regularly-to-frequently-win, or play-frequently-and-do-ok. If you just keep plugging away, your characters will continue to improve, and you'll stay reasonably competitive for a long time.  It's fairly easy to play entirely for free, though I'll admit I found there was a point somewhere around the mid-two-star level where I coughed up some actual money in order to not lose characters. In retrospect, this was unnecesary, but I didn't realize it at the time. I'd recommend reading through some of the great guides on the marvel puzzle quest forum for advice on which characters to keep and which to get rid of.

I think the most fun part of this game, over time, is that the developers truly seem interested in keeping it alive and interesting. I like how they keep introducing new mechanics.  I feel like sometimes they don't entirely think through the result of their actions on the way that people play the game.  For example, right now with new command points, rewards for people like myself working on their four-stars is definitely skewed to PvE rather than PvP.  I don't know if the developers did this intentionally, or just don't realize it.  But whatever. It's still fun, and somehow it's more fun for the fact that they're not entirely polished and thoughtful in their actions.   Some people get bent out of shape about this, but I actually think the chaos that comes with each new game mechanic or meta-change keeps things fresh.

I'd recommend it for the tablet or phone.  It's the perfect game to play once or twice a day over lunch break.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game on my android since it was released, I've easily put 50 hours into the game, I have 25 roster slots, over ten heroes that are Lv30+ all without spending a dollar. Don't put this game down for microtransactions since you don't need to spend a dollar with all the rewards the tournametns and the PvE gives you.

-Update-

I still see people are complaining about the Microtransactions.

1) If you play the game daily roughly 2 hours a day and do all the missions in the PVE events and PVP a couple times a day you should get roughly 3,000-5,000 Iso-8, the tool to level up your characters. It costs roughly 20k Iso-8 to max out any 1* Hero and roughly 80k to max out a 2* hero. You will be able to max out any 1* or 2* character within weeks of just playing a couple hours a day.

2. You will also roughly get a few hundred Hero Points in the process, if you are starting out the game. Use them on the 100 Daily Deal Heroic pack. That is how you max out your 2*s. If you have played the game for a while, save the Hero Points for Alliance slots, or join an open alliance. I created a 20 person alliance and only spent twenty bucks on it, I could have waited a month for the same ammount of Hero Points. ((Some people spent a hundred))

3. Now for the 3* covers, playing a lot in any tournament or event will nail you 1-3 3* covers of one hero. You will also get covers through the Heroic Packs and any other special pack that you spend your free hero points on. They require alot of Iso-8 to max out. 170k for a rough estimate. HOWEVER the final level still requires only 2500 iso-8, which is something you can easily get within an hour.

4. Guys this isn't a game that you get Lv100 of all the strongest characters within hours of playing. This game is set up more of an MMO where you have to do the slow grind to get to that point. I don't mind it. I currently have 5 maxed out 2* Characters at Lv85, 3 maxed out 1* characters and I have a handful of other 2 and 3* characters over lv50 with two that I just need to grind all the way to max level. I've only spent fifty bucks on this game because I actually felt like it. I didn't feel like I needed to in order to continue this game. To compare with other games I've played, I put almost a thousand bucks in to League of Legends and I had put six hundred bucks into Dungeon Fighter Online before that got shut down. I probably could spend more money into this game, but I don't.

reviewText:
First off, it is free. I personally have not paid one dime to the devs. And I have a full roster of rare, legendary, and gold characters. If you choose not to pay as I chose NOT to pay, then you must have patience. I only played when I wanted. I didn't get obssessed with the events. I simply played casually. And it all fell into place. I started with Ironman, Black Widow, and Juggernaut. Kept winning with that combination and started collecting several other characters. My favorite line up right now is Thor, Black Widow (rare), and Juggernaut (or Storm..again, rare one).

If you have patience and are not going to get swept up in having to win every event, not have to win every cover, not force yourself to play 3 or 4 hours a day then this game will be fine for you.

The game concept is simple: match tiles/blocks to destroy segments but with the Puzzle Quest twist of having special powers to activate once you collect certain colored tiles (AP).

I can confidently recommend this game. But you have to know what kind of player you are. If you need instant gratification and know you'll get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if you can't unlock all covers quickly or win every single event to get more covers, then don't play this game. If you feel you will reach into your pocket and throw all your money at this game to get a pay to win advantage and that is what is going to ♥♥♥♥ you off, then don't play this game.

But if you can enjoy the game casually it can be very rewarding.

And hey if you DO want to throw your money at it, then go ahead.

Either way the game actually is fun. I just have to tell myself not to get wrapped up in the treasures that always seem to be outside my grasp. I kept my money in my pocket and played casually (10 hours a week or less). And when I figured that out, treasures started falling in my lap.
