reviewText:
____MARVEL PUZZLE QUEST REVIEW____

Upon logging into steam and finding this featured in the store as F2P, A part of me leapt in excitement. As a long term puzzle quest lover I found myself drawn into the universe that is Marvel Puzzle Quest. Instead of having one character, you have up to 3 that switch in mid battle (each character is strongest with a particular tileset). As you match tiles, you gain the amount destroyed as power which you can then use as abilities.

This opened up some room for strategy, in which I would try to think 2-3 steps ahead and plan my attacks according to my characters strengths. The campaign is somewhat lackluster in the script department, with the cutscenes just being the same portraits as the ingame characters. However as you progress through the prologue, you are faced with goons that deploy timed tiles that explode after the timer expires. In certain situations you can be unlucky and not have any tiles nearby, but with careful planning, most tiles can be destroyed before their time expires. Going further into the campaign, these encounters just repeated, with very little varience.

However, there is plenty of varience in the somewhat multiplayer aspect of the game. Instead of fighting other players in realtime, the opponent's party is controlled by the AI, which is rather predictable (always uses abilites when they get appropriate power), but because you are fighting someone else's roster, you think about what strategy they were thinking about with their particular roster. This is somewhat compelling, but the real fun comes in the weekly events. Every week there is a particular event in which you compete with up to 1000 players for a chance to win rare covers. This brings me to my next point: the levelling system.

Instead of levelling like a normal rpg through experience points, you level by collecting the same cover with that particular ability and since heroes are level capped by the amount of covers they have, the more covers you have for a particular character, the higher you can level that character.This hampers progression and you will find that you will level the characters with the most covers instead of thinking about some strategy.  This is where the transactions come into play.

There are two types of currency: Iso-8, which is very common and can be generated by winning each game and awarded by winning particular events for the first time; and Hero points, which can be found in only a handful of stages in the PvE campaign. Conversely you can place in the top 25 in events and earn hero points, but to be able to do this, you need a good hero roster, which in turn requires hero points. Therefore every player will either have to wait 1 week for 50 hero points (hero points are awarded for logging in once per week) or they can choose to pay $1 for 100. At first this doesnt seem like a big issue. only $1 and you can have 100 hero points. However, the more roster slots you have, the more hero points it costs to upgrade. This is one area where the developers aimed their micro transactions at. I am guilty of spending $5 for 600 hero points to unlock a few more slots. I am currently up to 20 slots and have only paid $5 which I believe is reasonable. The other area where microtransactions seem tempting is the recovery time for your heroes.

As you battle, your heroes will get damaged. They will recover when they are not in use, but as you gain higher levels, the characters take longer to recover. For example, a level 1 Iron Man takes only about 10 minutes to fully recover, as apposed to a level 50 Iron Man, which takes 4 hours to recover. The whole aspect of waiting for characters to recover interrupts the flow of the game, which seems like a good idea when you're on the move/on a mobile device. However, this should have been removed with the PC version as most people can just play a few rounds, then they have to wait 2-3 hours to recover. You can instantly recover by using medkits which are somewhat rare, or can be purchased for 50 cents each. This price of 50 cents doesnt seem high, but when you have to do it almost every battle, you start to feel a pinch on your wallet.

One strategy that I believe newbies should employ (and this is only to help progression and to enjoy the game as it should be: uninterrupted) is to set your system clock forward. This tricks the game into thinking that time has passed and your characters will recover the amount of time you put the clock forward. Ignore the events, just focus on the prologue, get through it and level up your characters. Once you have finished the campaign, set your clock back to normal time and use 1 medkit on each character.

This trick" should not have to be used and it's bad gameplay design to have to resort to such things. However
recommended: I have put about 100 hours into this game over the last 2 weeks
hoursPlayed:
so they must be doing something right. Think of this game as a CCG with puzzle quest elements. Overall I would recommened this because it is free and you can still get a lot of enjoyment for free.

____Pros____

+Classic match 3 with marvel heroes
+Weekly events and login rewards
+Randomised PvP battles keep it fresh

____Cons____

-Progression hampered by random levelling system
-Cant battle steam friends in realtime
-Unable to sync IOS version with steam
-Predictable and repetitive AI"

reviewText:
I have to say, if you are a very competetive player you will NOT enjoy this game (or you'll spend a ton of time and money on it).  To this day, I have spent a wopping $5 on it, and that was more than enough for me. I got lucky and recieved a level 70 character.

At any rate, to the heart of the game:

It's a puzzle game. Your characters (3 per group) have skills that are powered by having so many of a specific color gem(s). So, you want to mix and match characters that will compliment the others. An example of this would be that some characters power is to change the colors of the gems. So if you have someone who changes gem colors to yellow and you have another character who does a power attack after getting so many yellow gems, have them on the same team.

In the game, there is a single story line you can go through and collect items: money for more character slots, tokens to get characters/skills, characters/skills, crystals to level your characters after equipping said skills, etc. The story mode does jump in difficulty, don't expect to sit down and hammer through it in an hour or two; it takes days, if not weeks (still not through them all).

In the meantime, there are daily events that link into I believe an almost two week long (if not longer -I came in to a season in progress so I'm not sure about the length) that you can do as well. The main seaon lasts a while, but there are dailies or longer events that come up.

The thing I lika about them, is they are not all versus other players (though those are available as well), some of them are solo events, and have a mix of using your current characters, or having some of your characters beefed up (some have your levels jump into the 100s), or even characters you don't have but are pretty beefed up that you can use as well.

I do need to point out though, that when your character runs out of health, you will either have to use a helath pack (one  returns in 35 minutes if you used them all) or just wait for them to heal over time.  As I have stated (and noticed from a lot of the negative comments), you really don't lose much over this if you aren't playing to be the best.

Patience, tactics, with a bit of luck, and you'll be fine.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Here's the problem.  If you get into this game, you will want to pay.  There is something about it that hooks into your hoarding instinct if you keep playing.   It is under constant development and the new characters keep it fresh.  That's worth paying something.

I played this on my phone for six months and then decided to start playing on the PC so that I have a better (bigger) interface.

My ground rules WERE:  No buying ISO-8 (experience points).  No paying for 10 packs or abilities.   Freely spend to buy slots when I win a new hero.   If you keep those rules, they payout is much like a subscription:   You win a couple of new characters every month and you pay a little to expand your roster.  Very reasonable.

Then they introduce a rare character like Professor X.   He's really good (4-star).  If you buy a 42 pack which features him (3.2% chance per card draw of getting one of his three abilities) then there is about a 25% chance you don't get him in the draw of 42 cards.  ((1.0-0.032)^42)   What's the chance of getting all three abilities in a 42 pack?  Haven't done the math, but it must be around 5% or worse.

So how much is a 42 pack?  15800 gold points.  You buy gold points for about 20000 for $100.   Therefore if you want a solid chance at getting all three abilities, you might pay about $400-$500.   You could get luckier.

Knowing all this, I still bought a 42 pack this week and got two of the three abilities.   I was very lucky and I can barely resist buying another 42 pack.  That is the hook.

Playing with the low level characters is very fun, there'se nothing wrong with it.  It's the desire and excitment about playing with a new one which makes you break your rules.

BTW, the endpoint for cost of a slot for a character seems to be about 850 gold per slot.  That's about $4.25 per character once you have a fullish roster.   If you win a character, you pay $4.25 to keep it.  Fine.   But then you want the other 2 abilities that you didn't win.   Keep that under control and you will find this game reasonably priced.

Oh, BTW, you do get all of the 1 and 2 star characters essentially for free over time and the cost of the extra slots is cheap at first.  It's the 3 and 4 stars that tempt you into paying.   You'll be happy in the moment and kind of sick in the long run.

I saw a comment on a review which pointed out that any free to play game that you play for more than a couple of hours should have a massive thumbs-up.  OK, so thumbs up for that.  You'll love it for 5 or 10 hours, then you have to start resisting the temptation to pay.

Having said all this, I can't argue with the thumbs-down reviews.  They're not bull####.  Watch your wallet if you start playing this, especially if you love it.

reviewText:
Highly Addictive
Casual game. Some sort of a blend of a card fighting game and a three-in-a-row game, with some twists.
Three of your heroes against one or more villains.
Your heroes have some powers that can be used, after they have collected some pieces of a certain color.
But, villains also have their own powers.
That makes more interesting the three-in-a-row game, because the goal is to defeat the villains, trying to use your powers and, trying to avoid villains to use their ones.
So, strategy is important.
While fighting, you can get some cristals, which you can use to train your heroes (level up them).
The bad side of this game is that your heroes go injured or dead and, there is a long waiting time until the health is being restablized, so you can end without being able to continue the game, until, maybe one day later.
And, there is where this FREE to play game wants you. If you are anxious, you can buy game coins (with real money) to buy medkits, cristals, enhancements or whatever you need to restore health and to train your heroes.
If you are ok being forced to leave the game until next day then, enjoy this game as it is.
Dialogues are forgettable (I bypass all them) and, are badly translated to Spanish. They add nothing to the game, IMHO.

reviewText:
Right so I've played this game for quite some time and it's a faily enjoyable timesink. I've been told it's like puzzle quest, only you have multiple people on your team so you can choose who to take hits from and there are more tactics to it.

There is a pay-to-win strategy in that you can spend all your money to get tokens to buy powerful heroes (or villains) and have them on your team. The most powerful ones are the most expensive ones, obviously, with the biggest level cap. You can sell old cards you don't want as you have a limited roster of heroes to have and a limit of 3 in each battle.

Beyond that, if you've played puzzle quest or any matching game you've got the idea of the game play to get at least 3 in a row, but here different characters deal different damage. For example, my group has Storm, Hawkeye and Iron Man. Iron Man deals the most damage with red so when they're matched he attacks and is open to attacks. Black ones Storm is most powerful at so she ends up in the firing line. they all have abilities based on colours you collect so there's also the tactic of wanting a really powerful ability to activate, but you can't use it unless you have X amount of this coloured jewel. For example, Iron Man's best power is Ultra Feron Beam which, at the moment, requires 19 Blue. 19 is a huge number, but with it he deals a huge amount of damage (which one-shots most villains by the time I get the amount) and even if it doesn't defeat them, it stuns them for 1 turn. Some abilities are direct attacks, stuns, destroys tiles, transforms tiles so depending on who's in your group, you can string together a large amount of abilities and combos to win the game.

I only play this at a time sink for when I want to hear background commentary on a game or movie and it works well for that. Also every day if you win a combat you get given a special daily reward which can be anything from hero points (also attained in game) to hero cards. You also  will want to re-play many battles as there are alternate rewards where you can have the chance to win 1 out of 4 choices, but only a chance which forces a grind, but a enjoyable grind.

reviewText: This game is getting a lot of flak for having micro transactions, which is true it does have a number of boosts or tokens you can buy to cheese your way through the game, but that can all be pretty much ignored. Each hero you use has HP which can get hurt during a stage, heroes automatically heal themselves over time or you can use a medikit for a full heal which auto regenerates over time. This kind of mechanic can be seen in a lot of F2P games like Farmville or Travian. I had gotten though the first level/city/whatever without needing to spend a dime and in the second area boosts made an appearance which yes, you can buy, but you will also receive free boosts just by playing. The only thing that got on my nerve is each stage has 2-4 rewards for beating the level which are unique the first time you receive it, but then if you would receive that same reward you get a paltry 20 ISO (in game resource) so if you want a full clear you have to continually do the same stage over and over.

reviewText:
I can really recommend this Puzzle Quest in the Marvel universe.

The adventures are plenty and fun, there are unique events every day so you won't get bored, and the tactics are nice and varied (big differences between fighting goons and fighting heroes). Since you play 3 characters with up to 3 powers each (and there are a lot of characters) you'll have plenty of choice and it's fun to maximize the efficiency of your team.

It does have a rather peculiar monetization system (it's free-to-play), which I have read nothing but negative comments about, but I honestly do not mind it at all, which is really weird since typically I wouldn't touch game like this with a 5 feet pole.

I watched TotalBiscuits WTF is.. of this game and so didn't expect much of it. Thought I'd deinstall in 5 mins. Instead I have been playing a lot. On and off while doing other stuff, just taking the time to let the heroes heal back up. Played this way, in between multitasking, I really like this game. I recommend you watch TotalBiscuits (or another) review though. The monetization system can put you off.

reviewText:
I really wish I could recommend this game. I really do. Unfortunately greedy developers have taken what should be a great casual gaming experience and turned it into a pay to win hell.
We'll start with the obvious-you get characters thrown at you so often and so fast that you're limited to giving up those characters when you run out of space or buying hero points to open up new slots. Strike 1.
Moving on: all those awesome characters you paid out to add to your roster? Yeah, you're gonna need a massive amount of ISO to level them. We're talking...2,000 matches worth of rewards to max level a single middle of the road 3* character. Of course you could always purchase more ISO with real money. No, really, its not insanely overpriced at all. I'm going to Hell for that particular lie. Strike 2.
Shall we try for the next point? Okay. Advancing your roster serves no purpose. None at all. The enemies scale up with you and quite often the devs mess up the scaling so badly that you're facing a team that can take out your best characters with absolutely no problem. I guarantee that at some point you will sit there, watching the screen while the AI systematically destroys those characters you worked so hard to level up. The only escape is to shut down the game as once the AI has started that turn that will end your team you wont be able to leave the match until every single animation has played out. And there's a lot of animations. Each clocking in at maybe 2-3 seconds and getting very annoying, very quickly. But that's alright. Once your team is destroyed you can fully heal your characters and give it another shot! Until you run out of health packs and have to pay to get extra of those as well. Strike 3.
TL; DR? Game will drain your wallet, crush your spirit and destroy your love of puzzle games. But you'll keep going back, not cos its fun but cos you've already invested so much effort into it.

reviewText:

It's good for me to just kill time. Don't expect to go very far into the game unless you want to deal with microtransactions.
